simple.usageInstructions: Launch the web interface with `@oglabs/mcp --web` to access server management features. Use `@oglabs/mcp --server` to run the MCP server mode for AI-powered server recommendations and analysis. For CLI-only usage, run `@oglabs/mcp`.

apple.name: Apple MCP Server
apple.description: Apple-native tools for the Model Context Protocol (MCP), enabling integration with various Apple apps and services.
apple.usageInstructions: 1. Install using 'npx -y @smithery/cli@latest install @Dhravya/apple-mcp --client claude'. 2. Configure claude_desktop_config.json with MCP server details. 3. Ask Claude to use the 'apple-mcp' tool with commands like 'send a message to John Doe' or 'create a reminder to Buy groceries for tomorrow at 5pm'.

mcpsqlserver.name: SQL Server MCP Server for Windsurf IDE
mcpsqlserver.description: A standalone MCP server providing SQL Server integration for Windsurf IDE.
mcpsqlserver.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/ian-cowley/MCPSqlServer.git && cd MCPSqlServer && dotnet build
mcpsqlserver.usageInstructions: 1. Build the project using 'dotnet build'. 2. Configure appsettings.json with your SQL Server details. 3. Update Windsurf MCP configuration to point to the built executable.

titan.name: Titan Memory MCP Server
titan.description: An MCP server providing neural memory tools for LLMs like Claude3.7 Sonnet, featuring memory management and persistence.
titan.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/henryhawke/mcp-titan.git && cd mcp-titan && npm install && npm run build && npm start
titan.usageInstructions: 1. Clone the repository and cd into it. 2. Run 'npm install' to install dependencies. 3. Run 'npm run build' to build the project. 4. Run 'npm start' to start the MCP server. 5. Configure Cursor or Claude Desktop to connect to the server at http://localhost:8080.

jenkins.name: Jenkins Server MCP
jenkins.description: An MCP server for interacting with Jenkins CI/CD servers, enabling AI assistants to check build statuses, trigger builds, and retrieve build logs.
jenkins.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/hekmon8/jenkins-server-mcp.git && cd jenkins-server-mcp && npm install && npm run build
jenkins.usageInstructions: Configure environment variables (JENKINS_URL, JENKINS_USER, JENKINS_TOKEN) in MCP settings file. Use tools like get_build_status, trigger_build, and get_build_log through MCP client.

discord.name: Discord MCP Server
discord.description: An MCP server providing Discord integration for MCP clients like Claude Desktop.
discord.usageInstructions: 1. Set up Discord bot via Discord Developer Portal. 2. Configure Claude Desktop settings with bot token. 3. Use Smithery CLI or manual installation via git clone and uv pip install.

sqlexpress.name: SQL Server Express MCP Server
sqlexpress.description: An MCP server for interacting with Microsoft SQL Server Express, supporting Windows and SQL Server authentication.
sqlexpress.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/hanweg/mcp-sqlexpress && cd mcp-sqlexpress && uv venv && .venv\Scripts\activate && uv pip install --editable .
sqlexpress.usageInstructions: 1. Clone the repository and create a virtual environment. 2. Install dependencies using 'uv pip install --editable .'. 3. Configure the 'claude_desktop_config.json' with the server command and arguments. 4. For Windows authentication, set '--auth windows' and '--trusted-connection yes'. For SQL Server authentication, set '--auth sql' and provide '--username' and '--password'.

sqlite-explorer-fastmcp.name: SQLite Explorer MCP Server
sqlite-explorer-fastmcp.description: An MCP server that provides safe, read-only access to SQLite databases through Model Context Protocol (MCP), built with the FastMCP framework.
sqlite-explorer-fastmcp.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/hannesrudolph/sqlite-explorer-fastmcp-mcp-server.git && cd sqlite-explorer-fastmcp-mcp-server && pip install -r requirements.txt
sqlite-explorer-fastmcp.usageInstructions: 1. Clone the repository and install dependencies. 2. Set the SQLITE_DB_PATH environment variable to the path of your SQLite database. 3. Use the 'fastmcp install' command or configure the Cline VSCode plugin to run the server. 4. Use the exposed MCP tools (read_query, list_tables, describe_table) to interact with the database.

openapi-schema.name: OpenAPI Schema Model Context Protocol Server
openapi-schema.description: An MCP server that exposes OpenAPI schema information to Large Language Models like Claude, allowing exploration of API specifications.
openapi-schema.usageInstructions: Run using 'npx -y mcp-openapi-schema [path/to/schema.yaml]'. For Claude Desktop integration, edit claude_desktop_config.json. For Claude Code, use 'claude mcp add [name] npx -y mcp-openapi-schema [path/to/schema.yaml]'

pptx.name: MCP PPTX Server
pptx.description: A FastMCP server for creating and manipulating PowerPoint presentations.
pptx.usageInstructions: After installation, use the FastMCP framework to interact with the server for PowerPoint creation and manipulation tasks. Ensure the FastMCP environment is properly configured for execution.

stata.name: Stata MCP Extension for VS Code and Cursor
stata.description: Provides Stata integration for Visual Studio Code and Cursor IDE using the Model Context Protocol (MCP), enabling execution of Stata commands, syntax highlighting, and AI assistant integration.
stata.usageInstructions: 1. Install the extension via VS Code or Cursor. 2. Open a Stata .do file. 3. Run commands using Ctrl+Shift+Enter (Mac: Cmd+Shift+Enter) for selected code or Ctrl+Shift+D (Mac: Cmd+Shift+D) for the entire file. 4. Configure settings like Stata path, server host, and log file location in VS Code/Cursor settings.

tpapi.name: ThemeParks.wiki API MCP Server
tpapi.description: MCP Server exposing ThemeParks.wiki API data for theme park operating hours, attraction wait times, and show times.
tpapi.usageInstructions: 1. Build the server using './gradlew build'. 2. Optionally build Docker image using './gradlew bootBuildImage --imageName=habuma/tpapi-mcp-server'. 3. Configure Claude Desktop by adding 'mcpServers' configuration to 'claude_desktop_config.json' with correct paths to Java and the JAR file.

research.name: Research MCP Server
research.description: An MCP server that integrates with Notion to retrieve survey data and create survey pages.
research.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/h-yanagawa/research-mcp-server.git && cd research-mcp-server && uv pip install -r requirements.txt
research.usageInstructions:
1. Clone the repository.
2. Obtain a Notion token from Notion Integrations.
3. Create a database page in Notion and retrieve the database ID.
4. Create a `.env` file with NOTION_TOKEN and NOTION_ROOT_DATABASE_ID.
5. Configure Claude Desktop Client by adding MCP server definition to `claude_desktop.json`.
6. Restart Claude Desktop Client.
7. Use Claude to perform a survey and review results.

pubmedmcp.name: PubMed MCP Server
pubmedmcp.description: An MCP server for searching and fetching biomedical literature from PubMed.
pubmedmcp.usageInstructions: Add pubmedmcp configuration to claude_desktop_config.json. Ensure uv is installed and 'uvx' is available in PATH. Configure UV_PRERELEASE and UV_PYTHON environment variables.

transistor.name: Transistor MCP Server
transistor.description: This MCP server provides tools to interact with the Transistor.fm API, allowing you to manage podcasts, episodes, and view analytics.
transistor.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/gxjansen/Transistor-MCP && cd Transistor-MCP && npm install
transistor.usageInstructions:
1. Clone the repository using 'git clone https://github.com/gxjansen/Transistor-MCP'.
2. Navigate to the directory and run 'npm install' to install dependencies.
3. Add the server to your MCP settings configuration file with your Transistor API key as shown in the README.
4. Use the provided tools to interact with the Transistor.fm API, such as listing shows, managing episodes, and retrieving analytics.

google-search.name: Google Search MCP Server
google-search.description: A Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that provides Google Custom Search functionality.
google-search.usageInstructions:
1. Create a `.env` file with `GOOGLE_API_KEY` and `GOOGLE_CSE_ID`.
2. Start the server using MCP: `mcp run google_search_mcp_server.py`.
3. Alternatively, add the server to the Claude Desktop app configuration file with the provided command example.

pubmed-search.name: PubMedSearch MCP Server
pubmed-search.description: An MCP server providing tools to search and retrieve academic papers from PubMed database.
pubmed-search.usageInstructions: 1. Start the server in development mode: 'mcp dev pubmed_search_mcp_server.py'. 2. Add server configuration to Claude Desktop app config.json. Ensure Python and required packages (fastmcp, requests, python-dotenv) are installed.

difyworkflow.name: MCP Dify Workflow Server
difyworkflow.description: An MCP server that implements query and invocation of Dify workflows.
difyworkflow.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/gotoolkits/mcp-difyworkflow-server.git && cd mcp-difyworkflow-server && make build
difyworkflow.usageInstructions: Configure the server by specifying DIFY_WORKFLOW_NAME and DIFY_API_KEYS in the env section of the MCP configuration file. Use commands like 'list_workflows' to list authorized workflows and 'execute_workflow' to execute a specified workflow.

graphlit.name: Graphlit MCP Server
graphlit.description: Model Context Protocol (MCP) Server for Graphlit Platform that enables integration between MCP clients and Graphlit service for knowledge management across developer and product management tools.
graphlit.usageInstructions:
1. Install Node.js (18.x or higher)
2. Create a Graphlit account and get your credentials from https://portal.graphlit.dev
3. Set environment variables GRAPHLIT_ORGANIZATION_ID, GRAPHLIT_ENVIRONMENT_ID, and GRAPHLIT_JWT_SECRET
4. Run 'npx -y graphlit-mcp-server' to start the server
5. Use with MCP clients like Cursor, Windsurf, Goose, or Cline

gotohuman.name: gotoHuman MCP Server
gotohuman.description: A Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that enables human-in-the-loop workflows for AI agents and agentic workflows with customizable approval UI, built-in authentication, webhooks, notifications, and team features.
gotohuman.usageInstructions: 1. Install the server using the command: `npx -y @gotohuman/mcp-server`. 2. Set the `GOTOHUMAN_API_KEY` environment variable with your API key. 3. Use the provided tools (`list-forms`, `get-form-schema`, `request-human-review-with-form`) to manage human approval workflows. 4. For local development, run `npm install`, `npm run build`, and configure the server in your MCP client (e.g., Cursor, Claude, or Windsurf) using the provided JSON configuration.

filesys.name: Filesystem MCP Server
filesys.description: A secure Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that provides filesystem operations with controlled access to specified directories.
filesys.usageInstructions: Set allowed directories using the environment variable: export MCP_ALLOWED_DIRS="/path1,/path2,/path with spaces/dir3". Add to claude_desktop_config.json with the command path and environment variables. Use the provided tools for file and directory operations.

gologin.name: GoLogin MCP Server
gologin.description: Manage GoLogin browser profiles and automation through AI conversations
gologin.usageInstructions:
1. Configure in Claude Desktop or Cursor using mcpServers configuration
2. Set API_TOKEN environment variable with your GoLogin API token
3. Restart the client to connect to the MCP server

genai-toolbox.name: MCP Toolbox for Databases
genai-toolbox.description: An open source MCP server for databases that simplifies development, improves performance, and enhances security by handling complexities like connection pooling and authentication.
genai-toolbox.usageInstructions:
1. Configure a tools.yaml file to define your tools.
2. Run the server using: ./toolbox --tools-file "tools.yaml"
3. Integrate with your application using the appropriate Client SDK (Python, LangChain, LlamaIndex, etc.)

wp.name: WordPress MCP Server
wp.description: A Python-based MCP server implementation for WordPress
wp.installCommand: uv venv && source .venv/bin/activate && uv pip install -r requirements.txt
wp.usageInstructions:
1. Clone the repository
2. Run `uv venv && source .venv/bin/activate && uv pip install -r requirements.txt`
3. Configure claude_desktop_config.json with the correct path to wp.py
4. Run the server with `uv run wp.py` (automatically managed by Claude)

audius-atris.name: Atris MCP for Audius
audius-atris.description: An MCP server providing comprehensive access to the Audius music platform via LLMs with 105 tools covering ~95% of the Audius Protocol API.
audius-atris.usageInstructions:
1. Install the package using `npm install audius-mcp-atris`.
2. Create a `.env` file with your Audius API credentials.
3. Start the server with `npm start`.
4. For development, use `npm run dev`.
5. Configure your LLM application (e.g., Claude) to use the server via the provided JSON configuration format.

hive.name: Hive MCP Server
hive.description: An MCP server that enables AI assistants to interact with the Hive blockchain through the Model Context Protocol, allowing operations like fetching account data, voting, creating posts, and sending encrypted messages.
hive.usageInstructions:
1. Set required environment variables for authentication (HIVE_USERNAME, HIVE_POSTING_KEY, HIVE_ACTIVE_KEY, HIVE_MEMO_KEY).
2. Use the MCP Inspector with `npx @modelcontextprotocol/inspector npx @gluneau/hive-mcp-server` for interactive testing.
3. Integrate with AI assistants like Claude Desktop, Windsurf, or Cursor by adding the server to their configuration files with the appropriate environment variables.
4. Use the server to perform actions such as fetching account info, creating posts, voting, and sending encrypted messages.

kokoro-tts.name: Kokoro TTS MCP Server
kokoro-tts.description: A Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that provides text-to-speech capabilities using the Kokoro TTS engine, enabling easy integration of speech synthesis into applications.
kokoro-tts.installCommand: curl -LsSf https://astral.sh/uv/install.sh | sh && uv venv && source .venv/bin/activate && uv pip install .
kokoro-tts.usageInstructions:
1. Install the server using the provided install command.
2. Use the MCP client to connect to the 'kokoro-tts' server.
3. Call the 'generate_speech' tool with the required 'text' parameter and optional parameters like 'voice', 'speed', 'save_path', and 'play_audio'.
4. Ensure audio playback tools (start, afplay, aplay) are available on your system for audio playback.

postiz-app.name: Postiz AI Social Media Scheduling Tool
postiz-app.description: Self-hosted social media scheduling tool with AI features, analytics, and team collaboration capabilities
postiz-app.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/gitroomhq/postiz-app.git && cd postiz-app && npm install && npm run build
postiz-app.usageInstructions:
1. Clone the repository and install dependencies
2. Configure PostgreSQL and Redis connections
3. Follow the Quick Start Guide at https://docs.postiz.com/quickstart for detailed setup

coding-standards.name: Coding Standards MCP Server
coding-standards.description: MCP server providing coding style guidelines and best practices for Java, Python, and React.
coding-standards.usageInstructions:
1. Install MCP package: pip install mcp
2. Install UV package manager (recommended)
3. Configure MCP client by adding server configuration to ~/.codeium/windsurf/mcp_config.json
4. Run in development mode: mcp dev server.py

ashra.name: Ashra MCP Server
ashra.description: A Model Context Protocol server for Ashra, integrating with Claude AI
ashra.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/getrupt/ashra-mcp.git && cd ashra-mcp && yarn && yarn build
ashra.usageInstructions: 1. Clone the repository and install dependencies using 'yarn'. 2. Build the project with 'yarn build'. 3. Configure Claude by creating 'claude_desktop_config.json' in the appropriate directory with the required 'ASHRA_API_KEY'.

graphiti.name: Graphiti
graphiti.description: Graphiti is a framework for building and querying temporally-aware knowledge graphs, specifically tailored for AI agents operating in dynamic environments.
graphiti.usageInstructions: 1. Install Graphiti using pip or uv. 2. Set up Neo4j or FalkorDB as the graph database backend. 3. Configure the required OpenAI API key. 4. Optionally set API keys for other LLM providers (Gemini, Anthropic, Groq). 5. Use the Graphiti framework to build and query knowledge graphs for AI agents.

lightning-tools.name: Lightning Tools MCP Server
lightning-tools.description: An MCP server that provides lightning address interaction and common lightning tools for integration with LLMs. Works with Alby's NWC MCP Server.
lightning-tools.usageInstructions:
1. Install Node.js 20+ and Yarn.
2. Use the install command: npx -y @getalby/lightning-tools-mcp-server.
3. Set the NWC_CONNECTION_STRING environment variable with your NWC connection string.
4. Add the server configuration to your claude_desktop_config.json or Cline prompt as shown in the README.
5. Optionally, build from source with yarn install, yarn build, and test with yarn inspect.

jessica.name: Project Jessica (ElevenLabs TTS MCP)
jessica.description: MCP server integrating ElevenLabs Text-to-Speech with Cursor through Model Context Protocol
jessica.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/georgi-io/jessica.git && cd jessica && python -m venv .venv && source .venv/bin/activate && poetry install && cp .env.example .env
jessica.usageInstructions:
1. Clone repository and cd into it
2. Create and activate virtual environment
3. Install backend dependencies using Poetry
4. Configure .env with ElevenLabs API key
5. Install pre-commit hooks
6. Start backend server
7. Configure Cursor MCP settings to connect to http://localhost:9020/sse

linear-go.name: Linear MCP Server
linear-go.description: An MCP server for Linear, providing tools to interact with the Linear API through the MCP protocol.
linear-go.installCommand: curl -L -o ./linear-mcp-go $(curl -s https://api.github.com/repos/geropl/linear-mcp-go/releases/latest | jq -r '.assets[] | select(.name | contains("$(uname -s | tr '[:upper:]' '[:lower:]')")) | .browser_download_url') && chmod +x ./linear-mcp-go
linear-go.usageInstructions:
1. Set LINEAR_API_KEY environment variable: export LINEAR_API_KEY=your_linear_api_key
2. Run the server: ./linear-mcp-go serve
3. For write access: ./linear-mcp-go serve --write-access

gemini.name: Gemini MCP Server
gemini.description: A TypeScript implementation of a Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that integrates with Google's Gemini Pro model.
gemini.usageInstructions:
1. Install the server via Smithery using the provided command.
2. Set the GEMINI_API_KEY environment variable with your Google Gemini API key.
3. Configure Claude Desktop with the provided JSON configuration to use the server.
4. The server will be available in Claude Desktop's MCP server list.

switchbot.name: SwitchBot MCP Server
switchbot.description: An MCP server providing SwitchBot device control capabilities to AI assistants.
switchbot.usageInstructions: 1. Install SwitchBot app and create account. 2. Get token and secret from Developer Options. 3. Configure claude_desktop_config.json with command, args, and env variables. 4. Set SWITCHBOT_TOKEN and SWITCHBOT_SECRET environment variables.

git-go.name: Git MCP Server (Go)
git-go.description: A Model Context Protocol (MCP) server for Git repository interaction and automation, written in Go. It provides tools to read, search, and manipulate Git repositories via Large Language Models.
git-go.usageInstructions:
1. Install the server using `go install github.com/geropl/git-mcp-go@latest`.
2. Use `git-mcp-go serve` to start the server with one or more repositories.
3. Use `git-mcp-go setup` to configure the server for use with an AI assistant like Cline.
4. The server supports multiple repositories and provides tools for Git operations such as status, diff, commit, push, and more.
5. For remote operations, enable `--write-access`.
6. Use `--auto-approve` to allow specific tools to run without user approval.

workers.name: workers-mcp
workers.description: Model Context Protocol (MCP) server implementation for Cloudflare Workers
workers.usageInstructions: The project has been moved to https://github.com/cloudflare/workers-mcp. Please refer to the new repository for installation and usage instructions.

discord-webhook.name: MCP Server Discord Webhook
discord-webhook.description: An MCP server for posting messages to Discord webhooks using the send_message tool.
discord-webhook.usageInstructions: 1. Install the package using `npm install @genpm/mcp-server-discord-webhook`. 2. Add the server configuration to your MCP configuration file as shown in the README. 3. Set the `DISCORD_WEBHOOK_URL` environment variable to your Discord webhook URL. 4. Use the `send_message` tool with required `content` and optional `username` and `avatar_url` parameters.

memory-file.name: MCP Server Memory File
memory-file.description: An MCP server that interacts with a memory text file to help Claude with inter-chat context.
memory-file.usageInstructions: To use this server, install it globally using npm, then configure it to point to your memory text file. The server provides tools for managing memories mid-chat, such as memory_add, memory_search, memory_delete, and memory_list.

bitbucket.name: Bitbucket Server MCP
bitbucket.description: MCP server for Bitbucket Server Pull Request management, providing tools to interact with the Bitbucket Server API through the Model Context Protocol.
bitbucket.usageInstructions: 1. Set BITBUCKET_DEFAULT_PROJECT if you want to use a default project. 2. Use commands like list_projects, list_repositories, create_pull_request, etc., with appropriate parameters. 3. For detailed usage examples, refer to the 'Usage Examples' section in the README.

commands.name: MCP Server Commands
commands.description: An MCP server that allows LLMs to run shell commands and return stdout/stderr.
commands.usageInstructions: To use with Claude Desktop, configure the server in claude_desktop_config.json. For HTTP interface, use 'uvx mcpo --port 3010 --api-key "supersecret" -- npx mcp-server-commands'. Logs are written to ~/Library/Logs/Claude/mcp-server-mcp-server-commands.log by default.

macos-defaults.name: mcp-server-macos-defaults
macos-defaults.description: MCP server for reading and writing macOS defaults (settings) using command-line tools like defaults read/write.
macos-defaults.usageInstructions:
1. Install using `uvx mcp-server-macos-defaults`.
2. Use the provided tools like `defaults-read`, `defaults-write`, `list-domains`, and `find` to interact with macOS defaults.
3. For development, clone the repository and run `uv run mcp-server-macos-defaults`.
4. For debugging, use the MCP Inspector by running `npx @modelcontextprotocol/inspector uv --directory /path/to/mcp-server-macos-defaults run mcp-server-macos-defaults`.

futuur.name: Futuur API MCP Integration
futuur.description: A TypeScript-based Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that integrates with the Futuur API to handle market data, categories, user information, and betting operations.
futuur.usageInstructions: 1. Install Node.js (LTS version) and npm/yarn. 2. Install the package using the install command. 3. Build the project with `npm run build`. 4. Run the server with `npx mcprunner FUTUUR_PUBLIC_KEY=... FUTUUR_PRIVATE_KEY=... -- node [path]/build/index.js`. Replace the keys with your actual Futuur API credentials.

inked.name: Inked MCP Server
inked.description: A powerful MCP server for memory management with Claude apps, featuring fast text search and optional AI-powered semantic search.
inked.usageInstructions: After installation, add to your MCP server configuration using 'npx @frgmt/inked' in the command field. Configure Claude settings to use the inked Read tool with 'ALL' to load memories and Write tool to save important information.

headline-vibes.name: Headline Vibes Analysis MCP Server
headline-vibes.description: An MCP server that analyzes sentiment in news headlines from major US publications, providing sentiment scoring and source distribution information.
headline-vibes.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/fred-em/headline-vibes.git && cd headline-vibes && npm install && npm run build
headline-vibes.usageInstructions: 1. Clone the repository and install dependencies. 2. Configure your NewsAPI key in the MCP settings file. 3. Use the analyze_headlines tool with natural language dates or specific dates.

pdfsearch-zed.name: PDF Search for Zed
pdfsearch-zed.description: A Zed extension that enables semantic search through PDF documents and integrates results into Zed's AI Assistant.
pdfsearch-zed.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/freespirit/pdfsearch-zed.git && cd pdfsearch-zed/pdf_rag && uv venv && uv sync
pdfsearch-zed.usageInstructions: 1. Clone the repository and set up the Python environment. 2. Set the OPENAI_API_KEY in src/pdf_rag/.env. 3. Build the search database using uv run src/pdf_rag/rag.py build with file/directory arguments. 4. Configure Zed's context_servers with the extension path. 5. Use /pdfsearch in Zed's AI Assistant panel to search PDFs.

custom.name: custom_mcp_servers
custom.description: A custom Model Context Protocol (MCP) server implementation for specialized use cases.
custom.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/francesliang/custom && cd custom && pip install -r requirements.txt
custom.usageInstructions: After installation, set the required environment variables (API_KEY, DATABASE_URL, SECRET_KEY). Start the server using 'python main.py'. Customize optional parameters like PORT and DEBUG for configuration.

hex.name: Hex MCP Server
hex.description: MCP server for Hex that implements various tools for managing Hex projects
hex.usageInstructions: After installation, configure using 'hex-mcp config --api-key "your_hex_api_key"' or set HEX_API_KEY environment variable. For Cursor integration, create .cursor/mcp.json with appropriate command configuration.

bloomy.name: Bloomy MCP
bloomy.description: A Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that connects to Bloom Growth's GraphQL API, enabling AI assistants to perform operations against the platform.
bloomy.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/franccesco/bloomy-mcp && cd bloomy-mcp && python -m venv .venv && source .venv/bin/activate && uv pip install -e .
bloomy.usageInstructions: 1. Clone the repository and set up a Python virtual environment. 2. Install the package in development mode using `uv pip install -e .` or `pip install -e .`. 3. Create a `.env` file with `BLOOM_API_URL` and `BLOOM_API_TOKEN`. 4. Start the server with `bloomy-server`. For Cursor integration, configure the server with the command `uv run --project /path/to/your/repo/ --env-file /path/to/your/repo/.env bloomy-server`. Use the MCP inspector tool with `npx @modelcontextprotocol/inspector bloomy-server` for development.

dicom.name: DICOM MCP Server
dicom.description: An MCP server for DICOM connectivity testing that allows listing DICOM nodes and performing C-ECHO operations.
dicom.installCommand: pip install uv && uv pip install mcp[cli]
optionalParams: nodes.yaml configuration parameters (e.g., node names, AE titles, IPs, ports)
dicom.usageInstructions:
1. Install UV: pip install uv
2. Install MCP server: uv pip install mcp[cli]
3. Configure nodes.yaml with DICOM node information
4. Run server: uv run server.py
5. Use MCP commands like list_dicom_nodes(), dicom_cecho_by_name(), or dicom_cecho() through Claude's MCP interface

foursquare-places.name: Foursquare Places MCP Server
foursquare-places.description: MCP server providing access to Foursquare Places API for location-based services and AI agent integration
foursquare-places.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/foursquare/foursquare-places-mcp.git && cd foursquare-places-mcp/fsq-server-python && uv pip install -r requirements.txt
foursquare-places.usageInstructions:
1. Clone the repository: git clone https://github.com/foursquare/foursquare-places-mcp.git
2. Create a Foursquare Service API Key following https://docs.foursquare.com/developer/docs/manage-service-api-keys
3. Set FOURSQUARE_SERVICE_API_KEY environment variable
4. Follow instructions in fsq-server-python/README.md for Python setup using uv
5. Download and install Claude Desktop App from https://claude.ai/download

folderr.name: Folderr MCP Server
folderr.description: A Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that provides tools to interact with Folderr's API, specifically for managing and communicating with Folderr Assistants.
optionalParams: Authentication token (via login or API key)
Base URL for the Folderr API
folderr.usageInstructions:
1. Add the server to your MCP settings with the command: `npx -y @folderr/folderr-mcp-server`.
2. Use the provided tools for authentication and assistant management:
   - `login` with email and password.
   - `set_api_token` with an API token from Folderr's developers section.
3. The server stores its configuration in a `config.json` file, including the authentication token and API base URL.
4. All assistant-related tools require authentication before use.

teams.name: Teams MCP Server
teams.description: An MCP server providing integration with Microsoft Graph APIs for Microsoft Teams, users, and organizational data.
teams.usageInstructions:
1. Install using: npx -y @floriscornel/teams-mcp@latest
2. Authenticate with Microsoft Graph using: npx @floriscornel/teams-mcp@latest authenticate
3. Configure in Cursor/Claude/VS Code using the provided JSON configuration
4. Requires Node.js 18+, Microsoft 365 account, and Azure App Registration with Microsoft Graph permissions

better-fetch.name: Better Fetch
better-fetch.description: A powerful Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that intelligently fetches and processes web content with nested URL crawling capabilities, transforming documentation sites into structured markdown for AI consumption.
better-fetch.usageInstructions: 1. Install via Smithery with the provided command. 2. Clone the repository and run `npm install` followed by `npm run build`. 3. Configure your MCP client with the server path. 4. Use the `fetch_website_nested` or `fetch_website_single` tools with appropriate parameters for crawling or single-page extraction.

sargoth.name: Sargoth Mermaid Renderer MCP Server
sargoth.description: AI-powered Mermaid diagram generation MCP server for converting natural language to professional visuals
sargoth.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/floor-licker/sargoth-mcp && cd sargoth-mcp && pip install -r requirements.txt && chmod +x mcp_server.py
sargoth.usageInstructions:
1. Configure AI assistant (Claude Desktop) with the MCP server path
2. Start the MCP server: python mcp_server.py
3. Use AI assistant to generate diagrams with commands like 'Create a sequence diagram showing how a user logs into a web application'

authenticator.name: Authenticator App MCP Server
authenticator.description: A secure Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that enables AI agents to retrieve 2FA codes and passwords from the Authenticator App, allowing automated login processes while maintaining security.
authenticator.usageInstructions: 1. Install the Authenticator App  2FA desktop version. 2. Create an access token in the Authenticator App settings under the MCP Server section. 3. Configure your AI agent's MCP server configuration with the command: `npx -y authenticator-mcp --access-token=YOUR-KEY`. 4. Use the AI agent to request 2FA codes or passwords for specific websites and accounts.

opnsense.name: OPNsense MCP Server
opnsense.description: A Python server implementing Anthropic's Model Context Protocol (MCP) to manage OPNsense firewalls using natural language through AI clients like Claude Desktop.
opnsense.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/floriangrousset/opnsense-mcp-server && cd opnsense-mcp-server && uv pip install -r requirements.txt
opnsense.usageInstructions: 1. Clone the repository and install dependencies. 2. Configure OPNsense API credentials. 3. Set up Claude Desktop with the MCP server configuration. 4. Use natural language commands to interact with your OPNsense firewall through the AI client.

genkit.name: Genkit AI Framework
genkit.description: An open-source framework for building full-stack AI-powered applications with unified interface for multiple AI models
genkit.usageInstructions:
1. Install Genkit CLI: npm install -g genkit-cli
2. Initialize Genkit with your model provider API key
3. Use Genkit SDK to build AI features
4. Deploy to Firebase, Google Cloud Run, or other environments

fetchserp-node.name: FetchSERP MCP Server
fetchserp-node.description: MCP server exposing FetchSERP API for SEO, SERP analysis, web scraping, and keyword research
fetchserp-node.usageInstructions:
1. Get FetchSERP API token from https://www.fetchserp.com 
2. Configure MCP client with npx/github registry or Docker 
3. Set FETCHSERP_API_TOKEN environment variable 
4. Optional: Run in HTTP mode by setting MCP_HTTP_MODE=true

findmine.name: FindMine Shopping Stylist
findmine.description: An MCP server that integrates FindMine's product styling and outfitting recommendations with Claude and other MCP-compatible applications.
findmine.usageInstructions: 1. Set the required environment variable FINDMINE_APP_ID with your FindMine application ID. 2. Run the server using the install command. 3. Use the provided API examples to interact with the server. For development, run in NODE_ENV=development to use sample data.

iterm.name: iterm-mcp
iterm.description: A Model Context Protocol server that provides access to your iTerm session, allowing models to inspect and interact with terminal output.
iterm.usageInstructions:
1. Ensure iTerm2 is running.
2. Add the server configuration to your Claude Desktop config file (as shown in the README).
3. Run the server via `npx -y iterm-mcp`.
4. Use the MCP Inspector for debugging by running `yarn run inspector` and accessing the provided URL.

placid.name: Placid.app MCP Server
placid.description: An MCP server implementation for integrating with Placid.app's API, providing tools for listing templates and generating images and videos.
placid.usageInstructions: 1. Install using the install command. 2. Configure PLACID_API_TOKEN environment variable with your Placid API token. 3. Add the server configuration to your Claude Desktop or Cline settings. 4. Use the provided tools like placid_list_templates, placid_generate_video, and placid_generate_image.

office.name: MCP Server Office
office.description: An MCP server providing tools to read and write Microsoft Word (docx) files.
office.usageInstructions: 1. Install using 'pip install mcp-server-office'. 2. Start the server with 'mcp-server-office'. Alternatively, use 'uvx mcp-server-office' if uv is available. Requires Python >=3.12 and dependencies mcp[cli] >=1.2.0 and python-docx >=1.1.2.

search1api.name: Search1API MCP Server
search1api.description: A Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that provides search and crawl functionality using Search1API, including web search, news search, and content extraction.
search1api.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/fatwang2/search1api-mcp.git && cd search1api-mcp && npm install
search1api.usageInstructions: 1. Clone the repository and navigate into the directory. 2. Set the SEARCH1API_KEY environment variable or create a .env file with your API key. 3. Run 'npm install' to install dependencies. 4. Run 'npm start' to start the server. For integration with LibreChat, follow the Docker setup instructions in the README.

intercom.name: MCP Intercom Server
intercom.description: A Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that provides access to Intercom conversations and chats for querying and analysis.
intercom.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/fabian1710/mcp-intercom.git && cd mcp-intercom && npm install
intercom.usageInstructions: 1. Clone the repository and install dependencies. 2. Copy `.env.example` to `.env` and add your Intercom API key. 3. Build the server with `npm run build`. 4. Start the server with `npm start`. 5. Configure Claude for Desktop with the server path and API key. 6. Use the `search-conversations` tool with optional filters like date ranges, source type, and conversation state.

f2c.name: F2C MCP Server
f2c.description: MCP server for Figma Design to Code conversion using F2C
optionalParams: Figma API tokens or configuration options
f2c.usageInstructions: Configure the server in an MCP-supported IDE, open chat in agent mode, paste Figma Node link, and enter requirements

explorium.name: Explorium MCP Server
explorium.description: An MCP server for interacting with Explorium API, enabling AI assistants to access business and prospect data.
explorium.usageInstructions: After installation, create a .env file with EXPLORIUM_API_KEY=your_api_key. For development, clone the repository, set up the environment using 'uv sync --group dev', and run 'mcp dev local_dev_server.py'. Configure AI assistants like Claude Desktop or Cursor to use the server.

file-merger.name: File Merger MCP Server
file-merger.description: A utility to merge multiple files into one, with features like fast merging, security, and detailed reporting.
file-merger.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/exoticknight/mcp-file-merger.git && cd mcp-file-merger && npm install && npm run build
file-merger.usageInstructions: 1. Clone the repository and install dependencies using the provided install command. 2. Configure the allowed directory by specifying the path in the command arguments. 3. Use the merge_files tool to combine files by providing input paths and an output path. 4. Optionally, use list_allowed_directories to check accessible directories.

steam.name: MCP Steam Server
steam.description: An MCP server that integrates with Steam API, providing functionality related to Steam user data and interactions.
steam.usageInstructions: To use this server, first build the project using './gradlew :bootJar'. Then, configure claude_desktop_config.json with your Steam ID and API key. The server is run using the command specified in the config file, pointing to the generated JAR file.

mistral-ocr.name: MCP Mistral OCR Server
mistral-ocr.description: An MCP server providing OCR capabilities using Mistral AI's OCR API, supporting local files and URLs.
mistral-ocr.installCommand: docker build -t mcp-mistral-ocr . && docker run -e MISTRAL_API_KEY=your_api_key -e OCR_DIR=/data/ocr -v /path/to/local/files:/data/ocr mcp-mistral-ocr
mistral-ocr.usageInstructions: 1. Configure Claude Desktop by adding the mcpServers configuration to claude_desktop_config.json. 2. Set MISTRAL_API_KEY and OCR_DIR environment variables. 3. Use tools like process_local_file or process_url_file to process files.

claude-task-master.name: Task Master
claude-task-master.description: A task management system for AI-driven development with Claude, designed to work seamlessly with Cursor AI.
claude-task-master.usageInstructions:
1. Add the Task Master MCP configuration to your editor's MCP config file (e.g., `~/.cursor/mcp.json`).
2. Replace placeholder API keys with your actual keys.
3. Enable Task Master in your editor's MCP settings.
4. Initialize Task Master in your project via the AI chat pane with 'Initialize taskmaster-ai in my project'.
5. Configure models using the AI chat pane with 'Change the main, research and fallback models to <model_name>'.
6. Create a PRD at `.taskmaster/docs/prd.txt` for new projects or use `scripts/prd.txt` for existing projects.

things-fastmcp.name: Things MCP Server
things-fastmcp.description: An MCP server that connects Claude Desktop with the Things task management app, allowing AI-powered task creation, analysis, and management.
things-fastmcp.usageInstructions:
1. Install Python 3.12+ and enable Things URL scheme in Settings -> General.
2. Install via pip: 'pip install things-mcp' or use the manual installation steps.
3. Set the THINGS_AUTH_TOKEN environment variable or use the configuration tool.
4. Configure Claude Desktop to use the Things MCP server by editing the configuration file.
5. Restart Claude Desktop and use natural language queries to manage tasks.

miro.name: MCP-MIRO Server
miro.description: A Model Context Protocol server to connect to the MIRO Whiteboard Application, enabling board manipulation, sticky creation, and bulk operations.
miro.usageInstructions: To use with Claude Desktop, configure the server in claude_desktop_config.json. On MacOS: ~/Library/Application Support/Claude/claude_desktop_config.json, On Windows: %APPDATA%/Claude/claude_desktop_config.json. Pass OAuth key as an environment variable or using the '--token' argument.

python-memory.name: Memory MCP Server
python-memory.description: A Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that provides knowledge graph functionality for managing entities, relations, and observations in memory with strict validation rules.
python-memory.usageInstructions: The server provides tools for managing a knowledge graph, including creating entities, adding observations, creating relations, searching memory, and deleting entities or relations. Use the provided Python code examples to interact with the server. Ensure the MEMORY_FILE_PATH is set for the server to function. The server supports validation rules for entity names, types, and relations.

personal.name: Personal MCP Server
personal.description: A Model Context Protocol server for personal health and well-being tracking, providing tools for workout logging, nutrition management, and journaling with AI-assisted analysis through Claude integration.
personal.usageInstructions: 1. Install the server using the provided command. 2. Set required environment variables like CLAUDE_API_KEY and DATABASE_URL. 3. Run the server with 'personal-mcp run'. 4. Use 'personal-mcp dev' for development mode or 'personal-mcp inspect' for debugging. 5. For Claude Desktop integration, run 'personal-mcp install --claude-desktop'.

rs.name: mcp-rs
rs.description: A Rust implementation of the Model Context Protocol (MCP) server, providing all core features of the original TypeScript implementation including authentication, middleware, and flexible transport options.
rs.usageInstructions: 1. Add `mcp-rs` to your Cargo.toml as a dependency. 2. Use the `Emcp` struct to create a new server instance. 3. Add tools, middleware, or authentication handlers as needed. 4. Start the server using the `start` method. Examples are provided in the repository for basic usage, authentication, middleware, and transport configuration.

hfspace.name: MCP HF Space Server
hfspace.description: MCP server connecting to Hugging Face Spaces for AI model interactions
hfspace.usageInstructions: Configure in claude_desktop_config.json with command and args, set working directory and Hugging Face token as needed

okx.name: OKX MCP Server
okx.description: An MCP server providing real-time cryptocurrency price data from OKX exchange through tools like get_candlesticks and get_price.
okx.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/esshka/okx-mcp.git && cd okx-mcp && npm install && npm run build
okx.usageInstructions: 1. Clone the repository and install dependencies using 'npm install'. 2. Build the server using 'npm run build'. 3. Configure the server in your MCP settings by adding the command and args. Example configuration for cline_mcp_settings.json: { "mcpServers": { "okx": { "command": "node", "args": ["/path/to/okx-mcp-server/build/index.js"], "disabled": false, "autoApprove": [] } } }

hn.name: Hacker News MCP Server
hn.description: An MCP server providing tools to fetch information from Hacker News, including story and user data.
hn.usageInstructions: To use this MCP server with Claude Desktop, update the claude_desktop_config.json file with the server configuration. For MacOS, the file is located at ~/Library/Application\ Support/Claude/claude_desktop_config.json. For Windows, it's at %APPDATA%/Claude/claude_desktop_config.json. Add the following configuration: { "mcpServers": { "mcp-hn": { "command": "uvx", "args": ["mcp-hn"] } } }

epsilla.name: MCP Epsilla Server
epsilla.description: A Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that integrates with Epsilla for database operations such as table creation, data insertion, querying, and deletion.
epsilla.usageInstructions: After installation, set the EPSILLA_API_KEY and EPSILLA_DATABASE_URL environment variables. Start the server using the provided CLI command. Use the exposed API endpoints to perform database operations like create/delete/list table, insert/query/get/delete data.

linkedin-runner.name: LinkedIn MCP Runner
linkedin-runner.description: An MCP server that enables GPT-based assistants to analyze and generate LinkedIn content based on a user's public profile and posts.
linkedin-runner.usageInstructions: 1. Authenticate with LiGo at ligo.ertiqah.com. 2. Generate and run the installation command provided. 3. Use Claude or ChatGPT to interact with the server for post analysis, rewriting, and brainstorming. Example: 'Analyze my last 5 posts. Whats working? Give me ideas on what I should write next.'

google-workspace.name: Google Workspace MCP Server
google-workspace.description: An MCP server providing Gmail and Google Calendar API interactions through a standardized interface.
google-workspace.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/epaproditus/google-workspace-mcp-server.git && cd google-workspace-mcp-server && npm install
google-workspace.usageInstructions:
1. Clone repository and install dependencies.
2. Create credentials.json with OAuth credentials.
3. Run node get-refresh-token.js to obtain refresh token.
4. Configure MCP settings in your IDE/app configuration file.
5. Build and run the server using 'npm run build'.

gcp.name: GCP MCP
gcp.description: A Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that enables AI assistants like Claude to interact with your Google Cloud Platform environment using natural language queries.
gcp.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/eniayomi/gcp-mcp && cd gcp-mcp && npm install
gcp.usageInstructions:
1. Set up GCP credentials using `gcloud auth application-default login`.
2. Configure your AI assistant (Claude Desktop, Cursor, or Windsurf) with the MCP server command.
3. Use natural language queries to interact with GCP resources, such as listing projects, checking billing status, or viewing logs.

pagespeed.name: MCP Server for Google PageSpeed Insights
pagespeed.description: An MCP server providing Google PageSpeed Insights analysis through a standardized interface.
pagespeed.usageInstructions:
1. Run 'npx mcp-server-pagespeed' to start the server.
2. Use the 'analyze_pagespeed' tool with a URL argument in your MCP client.

relay.name: MCP Relay
relay.description: MCP server that relays messages to Discord channels and receives responses
relay.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/emiliobool/MCP-Relay.git && cd MCP-Relay && npm install
relay.usageInstructions: 1. Create Discord application and bot. 2. Invite bot to server. 3. Get channel ID. 4. Configure MCP settings with DISCORD_TOKEN and DISCORD_CHANNEL_ID. Use send-message tool with required parameters: type, title, content. Optional: actions, timeout.

endaoment-postgres.name: Model Context Protocol PostgreSQL Server
endaoment-postgres.description: An MCP server that connects to a PostgreSQL database, allowing AI models to interact with the database through a standardized protocol.
endaoment-postgres.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/endaoment/endaoment-postgres-mcp && cd endaoment-postgres-mcp && npm install
endaoment-postgres.usageInstructions:
1. Clone the repository and install dependencies using the install command.
2. Create a `.env` file in the project root directory and set the `DB_CREDENTIALS` environment variable with your PostgreSQL credentials in JSON format.
3. Start the server using `node server.js` or `npm start`.
4. Use the `--verbose` or `-v` flag for detailed logging.
5. Integrate with Cursor by adding the server as an MCP server with the command `node /full/path/to/server.js`.

inbox-zero.name: Inbox Zero - AI Email Assistant
inbox-zero.description: An AI-powered email assistant and open-source email client that helps users manage and reduce their email workload efficiently.
inbox-zero.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/elie222/inbox-zero && cd inbox-zero && cp apps/web/.env.example apps/web/.env && cd apps/web && pnpm install
inbox-zero.usageInstructions:
1. Clone the repository and navigate to the project directory.
2. Copy the .env.example file to .env and fill in the required environment variables.
3. Install dependencies using pnpm install.
4. Set up Google OAuth credentials and Redis configuration as described in the README.
5. Run the application using the appropriate development or production command.
6. Access the application via the provided local development server or deploy using Vercel.

pr.name: MCP PR Reviewer Server
pr.description: An MCP server that reviews Pull Requests, adds comments, and saves reviews to Google Drive.
pr.installCommand: pip install mcp[cli] && pip install requests python-dotenv pydrive
pr.usageInstructions: 1. Clone the repository. 2. Create a .env file with GITHUB_TOKEN and optional GOOGLE_PARENT_FOLDER_ID. 3. Configure Claude Desktop with the provided JSON config. 4. Run the server using 'uv run pr-analyzer.py' or 'python pr-analyzer.py'.

freshservice.name: Freshservice MCP Server
freshservice.description: MCP server integrating Freshservice with AI models for IT service management operations
freshservice.usageInstructions:
1. Generate Freshservice API key from admin panel
2. Configure claude_desktop_config.json with API key and domain
3. Use Claude to perform Freshservice operations

ej-gdrive.name: ej-mcp-server-gdrive
ej-gdrive.description: An MCP server that integrates with Google Drive to allow listing, reading, and searching over files, including support for Google Workspace files (Docs, Sheets, etc.)
ej-gdrive.usageInstructions:
1. Create a Google Cloud project and enable the Google Drive API.
2. Configure an OAuth consent screen and create an OAuth Client ID for a Desktop App.
3. Download the OAuth JSON file and rename it to 'gcp-oauth.keys.json'.
4. Run the server with 'node ./dist auth' to authenticate and save credentials.
5. Use the server in your app's configuration with either Docker or NPX as shown in the README.

freshdesk.name: Freshdesk MCP Server
freshdesk.description: An MCP server implementation that integrates with Freshdesk, enabling AI models to interact with Freshdesk modules and perform various support operations.
freshdesk.usageInstructions:
1. Generate your Freshdesk API key from the Freshdesk admin panel.
2. Set up your domain and authentication details.
3. Add the configuration to your `claude_desktop_config.json` with the `FRESHDESK_API_KEY` and `FRESHDESK_DOMAIN` environment variables.
4. Use the server to perform Freshdesk operations like creating tickets, updating tickets, and managing agents and contacts.

mcpterm.name: mcpterm
mcpterm.description: An MCP tool server providing stateful, TUI-compatible terminal sessions, working well with Claude Desktop.
mcpterm.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/dwrtz/mcpterm.git && cd mcpterm && make && sudo mv bin/mcpterm /usr/local/bin/mcpterm
mcpterm.usageInstructions: 1. Clone the repository and build using 'make'. 2. Move the mcpterm binary to a directory in your PATH. 3. Configure Claude Desktop by editing claude_desktop_config.json to include mcpterm as an MCP server. 4. Restart Claude Desktop to use the tools provided by mcpterm.

garmin.name: Garmin Connect MCP Server
garmin.description: Server for interacting with Garmin Connect API to manage workouts and health metrics
garmin.usageInstructions:
1. Create .env file from .env_template
2. Run 'python example.py' to generate Garmin Connect token
3. Use 'mcp dev garmin_mcp_server.py' for development
4. Register server with 'mcp install garmin_mcp_server.py'

instagram-next.name: Instagram MCP Server
instagram-next.description: An MCP server for fetching Instagram posts using Chrome's existing login session
instagram-next.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/duhlink/instagram-server-next-mcp.git && cd instagram-server-next-mcp && npm install && npm run build
instagram-next.usageInstructions: 1. Set CHROME_USER_DATA_DIR environment variable to your Chrome profile path. 2. Run the server using: CHROME_USER_DATA_DIR=/path/to/chrome/profile npm start. 3. Use JSON-RPC2.0 requests to call tools like get_instagram_posts.

siri-shortcuts.name: Siri Shortcuts MCP Server
siri-shortcuts.description: This MCP server provides access to Siri shortcuts functionality via the Model Context Protocol (MCP), allowing listing, opening, and running shortcuts from the macOS Shortcuts app.
siri-shortcuts.usageInstructions: To use this server, add it to your MCP client configuration with the command `npx mcp-server-siri-shortcuts`. You can optionally set environment variables `GENERATE_SHORTCUT_TOOLS` and `INJECT_SHORTCUT_LIST` to customize behavior. The server provides base tools like `list_shortcuts`, `open_shortcut`, and `run_shortcut`, and dynamically generates tools for each available shortcut.

dynatrace.name: Dynatrace MCP Server
dynatrace.description: A remote MCP server that integrates with the Dynatrace observability platform to provide real-time data for development workflows.
dynatrace.usageInstructions:
1. Set up a Dynatrace OAuth client and obtain the client ID and secret.
2. Configure the required environment variables: DT_ENVIRONMENT, OAUTH_CLIENT_ID, and OAUTH_CLIENT_SECRET.
3. Optionally configure optional variables like SLACK_CONNECTION_ID, USE_APP_SETTINGS, and USE_WORKFLOWS.
4. Add the server to your MCP client (e.g., VS Code, Claude, Amazon Q Developer CLI) using the provided JSON configuration.
5. Use the server to query Dynatrace data, analyze problems, and automate workflows.

endoflife.name: EOL MCP Server
endoflife.description: An MCP server that checks software end-of-life (EOL) dates and support status using the endoflife.date API, enabling AI assistants like Claude to provide accurate software lifecycle and security information.
endoflife.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/ducthinh993/mcp-server-endoflife && cd mcp-server-endoflife && npm install && npm run build && npm link
optionalParams: Custom API endpoints for endoflife.date (if needed)
Port or host configuration for the server
endoflife.usageInstructions:
1. Install Node.js v18 or higher.
2. Clone the repository and install dependencies.
3. Build the project and create a global npm link.
4. Configure Claude Desktop by adding the EOL server configuration to claude_desktop_config.json with the command 'npx' and the path to the build/index.js file.
5. Restart Claude Desktop to verify the server is connected using the  icon.

arcknowledge.name: MCP ArcKnowledge Server
arcknowledge.description: An MCP server for managing custom webhook endpoints (knowledgebase) and querying registered document sources.
arcknowledge.usageInstructions:
1. Clone the repository: git clone https://github.com/dragonjump/mcp-arcknowledge && cd mcp-arcknowledge
2. Configure endpoints by modifying knowledge_document_sources.json
3. Create client configuration (claude_desktop_config.json for Claude or mcp.json for Cursor)
4. Run the server using: fastmcp dev main.py or fastmcp install main.py

mixpanel.name: Mixpanel MCP
mixpanel.description: A Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that interfaces with the Mixpanel API, allowing users to query events data, retention, and funnels from any MCP client like Cursor or Claude Desktop.
mixpanel.usageInstructions:
1. Go to Mixpanel Organization Settings to set up a Service Account and retrieve the username, password, and project ID.
2. Install the server using the provided install command.
3. For local execution, clone the repo, run `npm run build`, and execute the command with the service account credentials and project ID.
4. Use an MCP client like Cursor or Claude Desktop to query Mixpanel data (e.g., retention, events, funnels).

compresto.name: Compresto MCP Server
compresto.description: An MCP server providing AI assistants with real-time Compresto usage statistics
compresto.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/dqhieu/compresto-mcp && cd compresto-mcp && npm install && npm run build
compresto.usageInstructions: 1. Clone the repository and install dependencies. 2. Configure MCP settings with the server path. 3. Run with 'node build/index.js'

kospi-kosdaq-stock.name: kospi-kosdaq-stock-server
kospi-kosdaq-stock.description: An MCP server that provides KOSPI/KOSDAQ stock data using FastMCP, including OHLCV, market capitalization, fundamental data, and trading volume by investor type.
kospi-kosdaq-stock.usageInstructions:
1. Install the package using the command: uv pip install kospi-kosdaq-stock-server.
2. Configure the MCP server in your claude_desktop_config.json file by adding the server configuration under the 'mcpServers' object.
3. Restart Claude for the changes to take effect.
4. Use the server in Claude by invoking the appropriate tools such as load_all_tickers, get_stock_ohlcv, get_stock_market_cap, get_stock_fundamental, and get_stock_trading_volume with the required parameters.

dotenvx.name: dotenvx
dotenvx.description: A cross-platform environment variable manager that works with any language, framework, or platform, providing multi-environment support and encrypted environment variables.
dotenvx.usageInstructions: After installation, use `require('@dotenvx/dotenvx').config()` in your code to load environment variables from a .env file. For CLI usage, install globally via curl, brew, or other methods and use `dotenvx run -- [command]` to execute commands with environment variables loaded.

memory-service.name: MCP Memory Service
memory-service.description: An MCP server providing semantic memory and persistent storage capabilities for Claude Desktop using ChromaDB and sentence transformers.
memory-service.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/doobidoo/mcp-memory-service.git && cd mcp-memory-service && python -m venv venv && source venv/bin/activate && python install.py
memory-service.usageInstructions: Configure Claude Desktop by adding memory service configuration to claude_desktop_config.json. Use natural language commands to store, retrieve, and delete memories.

dbutils.name: MCP Database Utilities
dbutils.description: A versatile MCP service enabling AI to access various databases securely through unified connection configurations.
dbutils.usageInstructions: 1. Install using 'pip install mcp-dbutils'. 2. Create a YAML configuration file with database connection details. 3. Connect the configuration to your AI client. 4. Start interacting with your database using provided tools like dbutils-list-connections, dbutils-list-tables, etc.

airtable.name: Airtable MCP Server
airtable.description: A Model Context Protocol server that provides read and write access to Airtable databases, enabling LLMs to inspect database schemas and manipulate records.
airtable.usageInstructions:
1. Install the server globally using 'npm install -g airtable-mcp-server'.
2. Set your Airtable API key as the AIRTABLE_API_KEY environment variable.
3. Configure the server in your 'claude_desktop_config.json' file with the command 'npx -y airtable-mcp-server'.
4. Use the provided tools to interact with Airtable bases, tables, and records.

bybit.name: MCP Bybit API Interface
bybit.description: Provides a convenient interface to interact with the Bybit API using MCP tools, allowing market data fetching, account management, and order execution.
bybit.usageInstructions: 1. Set environment variables: ACCESS_KEY, SECRET_KEY (and optionally TESTNET). 2. Configure your MCP settings file with the server command and environment variables. 3. Run the server using the specified command (e.g., uv run or Docker). 4. Use the provided tools (get_orderbook, get_kline, etc.) to interact with the Bybit API.

memory-dashboard.name: MCP Memory Dashboard
memory-dashboard.description: A professional desktop application for managing and interacting with the MCP Memory Service, providing semantic memory management, search, and analytics with Docker ChromaDB integration for enhanced performance.
memory-dashboard.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/doobidoo/mcp-memory-dashboard.git && cd mcp-memory-dashboard && npm install
memory-dashboard.usageInstructions: 1. Clone the repository and install dependencies using the install command. 2. Create a `.env` file with the required environment variables for your system (macOS/Linux or Windows). 3. Set `VITE_USE_DIRECT_CHROMA_ACCESS=true` to enable Docker ChromaDB mode for improved performance. 4. Run `npm start` to launch the application. Ensure Docker is installed and configured if using Docker mode. For Windows, use double backslashes or forward slashes in file paths and configure PowerShell execution policy if needed.

minima.name: Minima
minima.description: Minima is an open source RAG on-premises container that integrates with ChatGPT and MCP, supporting fully local RAG functionality.
minima.usageInstructions: 1. Create a .env file with required variables. 2. For fully local installation: docker compose -f docker-compose-ollama.yml --env-file .env up --build. 3. For ChatGPT enabled: docker compose -f docker-compose-chatgpt.yml --env-file .env up --build. 4. For MCP integration: docker compose -f docker-compose-mcp.yml --env-file .env up --build. Ensure Python >= 3.10 and 'uv' is installed for MCP usage.

dev.name: MCP Development Server
dev.description: An MCP server enabling Claude to manage software development projects with complete project context awareness and Docker-based code execution.
dev.usageInstructions: 1. Install using 'pip install mcp-dev-server'. 2. Configure Claude Desktop by adding the server configuration to claude_desktop_config.json. 3. Ensure Python3.12+, Docker, and Git are installed.

rest-api.name: MCP REST API Tester
rest-api.description: A TypeScript-based MCP server for testing REST APIs through Cline, supporting various HTTP methods and authentication types.
rest-api.usageInstructions: 1. Install globally using npm. 2. Configure Cline custom instructions. 3. Add server to MCP configuration with required environment variables (REST_BASE_URL) and optional authentication parameters.

test.name: Log Analysis with SQLite MCP Server
test.description: A Model Context Protocol (MCP) SQLite server for querying log data stored in an SQLite database, with tools to create the database from compressed log files.
test.installCommand: python3 -m venv venv && source venv/bin/activate && pip3 install -r requirements.txt
test.usageInstructions:
1. Place compressed log files (.gz) in the project directory.
2. Run `python3 create_log_db.py` to create the SQLite database.
3. Configure the MCP SQLite server in Cursor by:
   - Going to Cursor Settings
   - Navigating to MCP
   - Adding a new MCP server
   - Naming it 'SQLlite'
   - Setting the type to 'command'
   - Using the command: `npx -y @smithery/cli@latest run mcp-server-sqlite-npx --config "{\"databasePath\":\"/path/to/thedatbase/logs.db\"}"`
4. Use `query_logs.py` to directly query the SQLite database.

cockroachdb.name: CockroachDB MCP Server
cockroachdb.description: MCP server that connects to CockroachDB, exposing database schemas and running SQL queries
cockroachdb.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/dhartunian/cockroachdb-mcp-server.git && cd cockroachdb-mcp-server && pnpm install && npx tsc
cockroachdb.usageInstructions: 1. Configure database URL and optional auth token. 2. Run with: node dist/server.js postgres://user:password@host:port/database [auth_token]. 3. Configure Claude for Desktop or Cline with the server.js path and connection details.

digma.name: Digma Code Observability MCP Server
digma.description: A Model Context Protocol (MCP) server implementation that enables agents to access observability insights using Digma for code observability and dynamic code analysis.
digma.usageInstructions:
1. Sign up for early access at https://digma.ai/mcp/ to obtain your DIGMA_API_URL and DIGMA_API_TOKEN.
2. Configure your MCP client (e.g., Claude, Cursor) to use the Digma MCP server by setting the URL as `https://<DIGMA_API_URL>/mcp/<DIGMA_API_TOKEN>/sse`.
3. For command-line usage, use SuperGateway with the command: `npx -y supergateway --sse https://<DIGMA_API_URL>/mcp/<DIGMA_API_TOKEN>/sse`.
4. Add a rules file to your `.cursor/rules` directory to define structured code review protocols based on runtime data.

devhub-cms.name: DevHub CMS MCP
devhub-cms.description: A Model Context Protocol (MCP) integration for managing content in the DevHub CMS system, enabling LLMs to interact with the CMS without direct API access.
devhub-cms.usageInstructions:
1. Install uv (https://github.com/astral-sh/uv) if not already installed.
2. Set the required environment variables: DEVHUB_API_KEY, DEVHUB_API_SECRET, and DEVHUB_BASE_URL.
3. Run the server using the command: uvx devhub-cms-mcp.
4. Configure the MCP in Claude Desktop or Cursor by adding the server configuration to the respective config file or using the CLI command as described in the README.
5. Use the available tools for business and location management, content management, and media management as outlined in the documentation.

debugg-ai.name: Debugg AI MCP Server
debugg-ai.description: AI-driven browser automation and E2E test server implementing the Model Context Protocol (MCP)
debugg-ai.usageInstructions:
1. Create a free account and generate an API Key at https://debugg.ai
2. Run the server using 'npx -y @debugg-ai/debugg-ai-mcp' or Docker command
3. Configure environment variables as needed
4. Integrate with MCP-compatible clients like Claude Desktop

qdrant-memory.name: MCP Qdrant Memory Server
qdrant-memory.description: MCP server providing knowledge graph implementation with semantic search capabilities using Qdrant vector database and OpenAI embeddings
qdrant-memory.usageInstructions:
1. Set required environment variables: OPENAI_API_KEY, QDRANT_URL, QDRANT_COLLECTION_NAME
2. Optionally set QDRANT_API_KEY if authentication is enabled
3. Run the server with: node dist/index.js
4. Use MCP client to call tools like create_entities, create_relations, and search_similar
5. For Docker deployment, build with 'docker build -t mcp-qdrant-memory .' and run with required environment variables

mcprfkgw.name: MCP Gateway for Voitta
mcprfkgw.description: This MCP server provides a gateway to the Voitta library, allowing you to use Voitta's capabilities through the Model Context Protocol (MCP). It supports both STDIO and SSE transports.
mcprfkgw.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/debedb/mcprfkgw && cd mcprfkgw && pip install -r requirements.txt
mcprfkgw.usageInstructions: 1. Clone the repository and install dependencies. 2. Configure the Voitta configuration file path using the CONFIG_PATH environment variable. 3. Run the server using `python server.py` for STDIO transport or `FASTMCP_HTTP=1 PORT=10000 python server.py` for HTTP/SSE transport. 4. Use the MCP Inspector to test and debug the server by connecting via STDIO or SSE.

mysql-query.name: MySQL Query MCP Server
mysql-query.description: An MCP server providing read-only MySQL database queries for AI assistants.
mysql-query.usageInstructions: 1. Install globally using 'npm install -g mysql-query-mcp-server' or run with 'npx mysql-query-mcp-server'. 2. Configure your AI tool with the MCP server details in .cursor/mcp.json. 3. Set required environment variables for database credentials. 4. Configure additional settings like DEBUG and SSL options as needed.

clever-demo.name: MCP Clever Demo
clever-demo.description: An MCP server built with the JavaScript SDK that integrates Clever Cloud tools for use in MCP clients.
clever-demo.usageInstructions: To use this server in an MCP client, configure it with the command `npx -y mcp-clever-demo`. For local development, run the server using the MCP Inspector with the command `npx @modelcontextprotocol/inspector npx mcp-clever-demo`.

jupiter.name: MCP Jupiter Server
jupiter.description: An MCP server providing Claude with access to Jupiter's swap API on Solana blockchain
jupiter.usageInstructions: 1. Configure Claude Desktop by editing claude_desktop_config.json to include the MCP server configuration. 2. Restart Claude Desktop. 3. Use Claude to interact with Jupiter's swap API by asking for quotes, building swap transactions, or sending swap transactions.

git-forensics.name: Git Forensics MCP
git-forensics.description: A specialized MCP server for deep git repository investigation and analysis, providing insights into repository history and development patterns.
git-forensics.usageInstructions: 1. Install Git and Node.js. 2. Run the server using MCP-compatible client. 3. Configure repoPath and other parameters as needed.

git-file-forensics.name: Git File Forensics MCP
git-file-forensics.description: An MCP tool for deep git file-level forensics that analyzes file histories, changes, and patterns.
git-file-forensics.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/davidorex/git-file-forensics && cd git-file-forensics && npm install && npm run build
git-file-forensics.usageInstructions: 1. Clone and build the server. 2. Configure MCP settings with the server path. 3. Use tools like track_file_versions, analyze_file_diff, analyze_file_context, analyze_file_semantics via MCP protocol. Requires Node.js and Git to be installed.

on-aws-bedrock.name: MCP on AWS Bedrock
on-aws-bedrock.description: A simple and clear example for implementing and understanding Anthropic's Model Context Protocol (MCP) with AWS Bedrock.
on-aws-bedrock.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/davidshtian/MCP-on-AWS-Bedrock && cd MCP-on-AWS-Bedrock && uv pip install -r requirements.txt
on-aws-bedrock.usageInstructions: 1. Clone the repository and install dependencies. 2. Set AWS credentials as environment variables. 3. Run the server with `uv run fetch_url_mcp_server.py` for default stdio or with `--transport streamable-http` for HTTP transport. 4. Use the appropriate client script (`client_stdio.py` or `client_streamablehttp.py`) to interact with the server.

snowflake-service.name: MCP Snowflake Service
snowflake-service.description: An MCP server providing Claude access to Snowflake databases with automatic connection management and query execution.
snowflake-service.usageInstructions: 1. Configure Claude Desktop by adding 'mcpServers' entry to claude_desktop_config.json. 2. Create .env file with Snowflake credentials. 3. The server will start automatically with Claude Desktop.

scast.name: SCAST
scast.description: SCAST is a programmatic tool that converts code into UML diagrams and flowcharts using static analysis and visualization libraries like Mermaid and D3. It supports integration as an MCP server for code analysis and visualization.
scast.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/davidkingzyb/SCAST.git && cd SCAST && npm install
scast.usageInstructions: 1. Clone the repository and install dependencies with `npm install`. 2. Configure the MCP server in your client with the provided JSON configuration. 3. Use `scast_analysis` and `scast_retriever` tools for code analysis and visualization. 4. For deployment, run `npm run server`. Ensure Ollama is installed for AI integration.

toy.name: Toy MCP Server
toy.description: A simple Model Context Protocol (MCP) server-client architecture that fetches data from the HackerNews API.
toy.usageInstructions: After installation, start the server using the provided CLI command. The server will fetch data from the HackerNews API. You can customize the server behavior using optional environment variables like PORT and DEBUG.

kpu.name: KeywordsPeopleUse MCP Server
kpu.description: An MCP server implementation integrating with KeywordsPeopleUse for keyword research features.
kpu.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/data-skunks/kpu-mcp.git && cd kpu-mcp && npm install
kpu.usageInstructions: 1. Clone the repository and install dependencies. 2. Get your API key from KeywordsPeopleUse Settings. 3. Create a .env file with KPU_API_KEY=your_api_key. 4. Configure Cursor or Claude Desktop with the appropriate MCP server settings using the path to the index.js file.

astra-db.name: Astra DB MCP Server
astra-db.description: A Model Context Protocol (MCP) server for interacting with Astra DB, allowing Large Language Models (LLMs) to act as agents for database operations.
astra-db.usageInstructions: To use the Astra DB MCP Server, first install it globally using 'npm install -g @datastax/astra-db-mcp'. Then, configure your MCP client (e.g., Claude Desktop or Cursor) with the server by providing the required environment variables: ASTRA_DB_APPLICATION_TOKEN and ASTRA_DB_API_ENDPOINT. Optionally, specify ASTRA_DB_KEYSPACE if you need to connect to a specific keyspace. Add the server configuration to your MCP client's settings as described in the README for integration.

multi-agent-with.name: LangGraph Coding Agent Team with MCP
multi-agent-with.description: A multi-agent coding team using LangGraph and Model Context Protocol (MCP) for collaborative coding tasks
multi-agent-with.installCommand: pip install -e . && cd gateway && pip install -e . && cd ..
multi-agent-with.usageInstructions:
1. Configure environment variables in .env file
2. Configure MCP servers in gateway/config.json
3. Start gateway server: cd gateway && python -m mcp_gateway.server
4. Open project in LangGraph Studio

fillout.name: Fillout.io MCP Server
fillout.description: MCP Server for the Fillout.io API, enabling form management, response handling, and analytics for digital forms and surveys.
fillout.usageInstructions:
1. Obtain a Fillout.io API key from your account settings.
2. Set the FILLOUT_API_KEY environment variable with your key.
3. Use the server to manage forms, submit responses, and retrieve analytics.
4. For Docker usage, run: docker run -e FILLOUT_API_KEY=your-key mcp/fillout.
5. For local development, install dependencies with npm install and run with npm run dev.

decent-sampler-drums.name: Decent Sampler Drums MCP Server
decent-sampler-drums.description: An MCP server for generating Decent Sampler drum kit configurations with features like WAV analysis and XML generation.

nostrdb.name: nostrdb-mcp
nostrdb.description: A Model Context Protocol server that enables LLMs to use the `ndb` nostrdb command line tool for local nostr queries.
optionalParams: GOOSE_PROVIDER (for configuring goose with the MCP server)
nostrdb.usageInstructions: 1. Ensure `ndb` is installed and available on your PATH by compiling it from the nostrdb repo. 2. Install goose globally with `npm install -g goose`. 3. Configure goose with `goose configure` and add the provider using `npx -y nostrdb-mcp`. 4. Start a session with `goose session --with-extension npx -y nostrdb-mcp` to test the server.

daisys.name: Daisys MCP Server
daisys.description: MCP server integrating with Daisys AI services for audio processing
daisys.usageInstructions: 1. Get Daisys account and credentials. 2. Configure MCP client with Daisys credentials and storage path. For macOS: 'brew install portaudio'. For Linux: 'sudo apt install portaudio19-dev libjack-dev'.

devdb-vscode.name: DevDb
devdb-vscode.description: A VS Code extension that auto-loads database and provides database affordances for development and debugging.
devdb-vscode.usageInstructions: 1. Ensure VS Code is installed (version 1.83 or newer). 2. Install DevDb extension from VS Code marketplace. 3. Open a project using a supported database. 4. Use 'Cmd + K + D' to toggle DevDb view panel or 'Cmd + K + G' to go to a table.

userfuls.name: Useful Model Context Protocol Servers (MCPs)
userfuls.description: A collection of standalone Python scripts implementing Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers for various utility functions such as YouTube data extraction, Word document processing, PlantUML rendering, Mermaid rendering, and RSS feed to markdown conversion.
userfuls.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/daltonnyx/userful-mcps.git && cd useful-mcps && pip install uv
userfuls.usageInstructions: 1. Clone the repository and install uv. 2. Run each MCP server using `uv run --directory <path/to/mcp> <script_name>`. For example: `uv run --directory ./ytdlp ytdlp_mcp`. 3. Configure your MCP client with the provided JSON configurations for each server. 4. Set required environment variables like MERMAID_CHART_ACCESS_TOKEN before running the Mermaid server.

docsmcp.name: DocsMCP
docsmcp.description: An MCP server providing documentation access to LLMs from local files or remote URLs.
docsmcp.usageInstructions: Configure DocsMCP in Cursor by creating a .cursor/mcp.json file or in VS Code by creating a .vscode/mcp.json file. Use 'npx -y docsmcp' with appropriate arguments like '--source=Model Context Protocol (MCP)|https://modelcontextprotocol.io/llms-full.txt'

logseq.name: Logseq MCP Server
logseq.description: A Model Context Protocol server that provides direct integration with Logseq's knowledge base, enabling LLMs to interact with Logseq graphs, create pages, manage blocks, and organize information programmatically.
logseq.usageInstructions:
1. Generate an API token in Logseq under API  Authorization tokens.
2. Set the LOGSEQ_API_TOKEN and LOGSEQ_API_URL environment variables.
3. Run the server using `python -m mcp_server_logseq`.
4. Use the provided JSON configuration in an MCP client (e.g., Claude Desktop) to connect to the server with the specified command and environment variables.

lattice-hq.name: Lattice HQ MCP Server
lattice-hq.description: An MCP server for Lattice HQ that enables AI models to interact with Lattice performance management platform.
lattice-hq.usageInstructions:
1. Get Lattice API token from Settings  Integrations  API or contact Lattice Support.
2. Run: LATTICE_API_URL=https://your-company.latticehq.com lattice-hq-mcp-server --api-key=YOUR-TOKEN --stdio
3. For Claude Desktop, add configuration to claude_desktop_config.json.

elasticsearch.name: Elasticsearch MCP Server
elasticsearch.description: A Model Context Protocol server for Elasticsearch clusters that enables LLMs to manage indices and execute queries.
elasticsearch.usageInstructions:
1. Install the package using `npx -y @modelcontextprotocol/server-elasticsearch`.
2. Set the `ELASTICSEARCH_URL` environment variable to your Elasticsearch endpoint.
3. Optionally configure additional parameters like `discovery.type` or `xpack.security.enabled` if needed.
4. Add the server to the `mcpServers` section of your `claude_desktop_config.json` to use with Claude Desktop.
5. Run Elasticsearch locally using the provided Docker command if needed.

cycode-cli.name: Cycode CLI
cycode-cli.description: Cycode Command Line Interface for scanning repositories for secrets, infrastructure misconfigurations, software composition analysis vulnerabilities, and static application security testing issues.
cycode-cli.usageInstructions: 1. Install using 'pip3 install cycode'. 2. Authenticate using 'cycode auth' or 'cycode configure'. 3. Set environment variables CYCODE_CLIENT_ID and CYCODE_CLIENT_SECRET if needed.

cyclops.name: Cyclops MCP Server
