cyclops.description: Cyclops MCP allows AI agents to manage Kubernetes applications by abstracting Kubernetes complexity into high-level resources.
cyclops.usageInstructions:
1. Ensure Cyclops is installed in your Kubernetes cluster.
2. Download the Cyclops MCP server binary using the install command.
3. Configure the server using environment variables like KUBECONFIG and CYCLOPS_MODULE_NAMESPACE.
4. Expose the server via kubectl port-forward and connect it to an AI agent using the provided JSON configuration.

abp-io.name: ABP.IO MCP Server
abp-io.description: A comprehensive Model Context Protocol (MCP) server for ABP.IO that enables AI models to interact with ABP applications, providing 48+ tools for managing modules, entities, users, tenants, UI development, and more.
abp-io.usageInstructions:
1. Use npx to run the server directly: `npx abp-io-mcp-server --api-key=YOUR_API_KEY --base-url=https://your-abp-app.com --stdio`.
2. For global installation: `npm install -g abp-io-mcp-server`.
3. For local development: Clone the repo, install dependencies with `npm install`, build with `npm run build`, and run with `npm run dev`.
4. Configure environment variables `ABP_API_KEY` and `ABP_BASE_URL` for authentication and base URL.
5. Use the server with Claude Desktop or other MCP clients by configuring the `mcpServers` section in the client's config file.

toolkit.name: toolkit-mcp-server
toolkit.description: A Model Context Protocol server providing LLM Agents with system utilities and tools, including IP geolocation, network diagnostics, system monitoring, cryptographic operations, and QR code generation.
toolkit.usageInstructions: 1. Install the package using `npm install @cyanheads/toolkit-mcp-server`. 2. Add the server to your MCP client settings with the command `node` and the path to the server's build file. 3. Use the provided tools for network, system, security, and generator operations as shown in the example code snippets.

llm-context.py.name: LLM Context
llm-context.py.description: A tool for injecting relevant project content into Large Language Model chat interfaces, supporting both CLI and MCP protocol integration.
llm-context.py.usageInstructions:
1. Initialize project: lc-init
2. Select files: lc-sel-files
3. Generate context: lc-context
4. For MCP with Claude Desktop, configure claude_desktop_config.json as described in Quickstart section

postgres.name: Postgres MCP Pro
postgres.description: An open source Model Context Protocol (MCP) server for Postgres database management with features like index tuning, query plans, and health checks.
postgres.usageInstructions: 1. Install using 'uv pip install postgres-mcp' or Docker. 2. Configure Claude Desktop or other MCP client with the server details. 3. Set DATABASE_URI environment variable with Postgres connection string. 4. Choose access mode: unrestricted for development or restricted for production.

scryfall.name: Scryfall MCP Server
scryfall.description: An MCP server that provides access to the Scryfall API for Magic: The Gathering card data, rulings, and pricing.
scryfall.usageInstructions: Run the server in stdio mode with `npx scryfall-mcp-server` or in SSE mode with `npx scryfall-mcp-server --sse`. For Docker usage, build with `docker build -t mcp/scryfall .` and run in stdio or SSE mode as needed. Connect via stdio or use the SSE endpoint at `http://localhost:3000/sse`.

snapshot.name: MCP Snapshot Server
snapshot.description: A Model Context Protocol server for interacting with Snapshot.org, providing tools to query Snapshot spaces, proposals, and users.
snapshot.usageInstructions: 1. Install the package using `npm install mcp-snapshot-server`. 2. Configure the server in your Claude Desktop config file by specifying the command and path to the built `index.js`. 3. Use available tools like `getSpaces`, `getProposals`, `getProposal`, `getRankedSpaces`, and `getUser` with optional parameters to query Snapshot data.

expert.name: MCP Expert Server
expert.description: An MCP server providing intelligent query generation and documentation assistance using Claude AI.
expert.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/crazyrabbitLTC/mcp-expert-server.git && cd mcp-expert-server && npm install && npm run build && npm run setup
expert.usageInstructions:
1. Create a .env file with ANTHROPIC_API_KEY
2. Add API documentation files to docs/ directory
3. Optionally customize prompts in prompts/ directory
4. Start server with 'npm start'

twitter.name: X (Twitter) MCP Server
twitter.description: A comprehensive Model Context Protocol server implementation for X (Twitter) API integration with professional workflow automation and enhanced research capabilities.
twitter.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/crazyrabbitLTC/mcp-twitter-server.git && cd mcp-twitter-server && npm install
twitter.usageInstructions:
1. Clone the repository and install dependencies.
2. Create .env file from .env.example and configure your Twitter API credentials.
3. Run 'npm run build' and then 'npm start' to start the server.
4. Test the server using JSON-RPC calls as shown in the README.

higress-ai-search.name: Higress AI-Search MCP Server
higress-ai-search.description: An MCP server providing AI search capabilities through Higress ai-search feature, enhancing AI model responses with real-time search results.
higress-ai-search.usageInstructions: Configure the server by setting required environment variables (MODEL) and optional configuration (HIGRESS_URL, INTERNAL_KNOWLEDGE_BASES). Ensure Higress is configured with ai-search and ai-proxy plugins.

crawlab.name: Crawlab MCP Server
crawlab.description: A Model Context Protocol (MCP) server for Crawlab, enabling AI applications to interact with Crawlab's spider and task management features.
crawlab.usageInstructions:
1. Install dependencies using `pip install -r requirements.txt`.
2. Copy `.env.example` to `.env` and update with your Crawlab API details.
3. Run the server using `python server.py`.
4. Start the MCP client with `crawlab_mcp-mcp client SERVER_URL`.
5. Use the MCP server with AI applications by connecting them to the server URL.

numpy.name: NumPy MCP Server
numpy.description: A Model Context Protocol (MCP) server for numerical computations using NumPy, enabling mathematical operations through MCP-compatible LLMs.
numpy.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/colesmcintosh/numpy-mcp.git && cd numpy-mcp && curl -LsSf https://astral.sh/uv/install.sh | sh && uv venv && source .venv/bin/activate && uv pip install -r requirements.txt
numpy.usageInstructions:
1. Install the server using the provided install command.
2. Test the server locally with the MCP Inspector using 'mcp dev server.py'.
3. For Claude Desktop integration, run 'mcp install server.py --name "NumPy Calculator"'.
4. Use the server by asking Claude to perform mathematical operations, such as calculating eigenvalues, statistical analysis, or polynomial fitting.

dexpaprika.name: DexPaprika MCP Server
dexpaprika.description: An MCP server providing on-demand access to cryptocurrency and DEX data API for AI assistants like Claude.
dexpaprika.usageInstructions: 1. Install using 'npm install -g dexpaprika-mcp'. 2. Start the server with 'dexpaprika-mcp'. 3. Configure Claude Desktop by adding the server details to claude_desktop_config.json.

file-tool.name: MCP File Server
file-tool.description: An MCP server implementation providing file system operations through a standardized interface.
file-tool.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/codyde/mcp-file-tool.git && cd mcp-file-tool && npm install
file-tool.usageInstructions: Start the server with 'node src/index.js'. The server communicates through stdin/stdout using the MCP protocol. Configure SENTRY_DSN for error tracking if needed.

firecrawl-tool.name: MCP Firecrawl Server
firecrawl-tool.description: A simple MCP server that provides tools to scrape websites and extract structured data using Firecrawl's APIs.
firecrawl-tool.usageInstructions: 1. Create a `.env` file with FIRECRAWL_API_TOKEN and optionally SENTRY_DSN. 2. Run `npm start` to start the server. 3. Use the `scrape-website` and `extract-data` tools with MCP Inspector to scrape websites and extract structured data.

google-ads.name: Google Ads MCP
google-ads.description: A tool that connects Google Ads with Claude AI, allowing analysis of advertising data through natural language conversations.
google-ads.usageInstructions: 1. Set up Google Ads API access using either OAuth2.0 Client ID or Service Account authentication. 2. Configure environment variables. 3. Run the server.

coingecko-typescript.name: Coingecko TypeScript API Library
coingecko-typescript.description: A TypeScript library for accessing the Coingecko REST API, providing convenient access to cryptocurrency data with full TypeScript support.
coingecko-typescript.usageInstructions: Import the library and initialize the client with your Coingecko Pro API key. Use the client to make API requests, such as fetching cryptocurrency prices. Optional parameters like environment, maxRetries, timeout, and logLevel can be configured for advanced usage. Error handling is supported with APIError subclasses for different HTTP status codes.

cloudbrowser.name: Cloud Browser MCP Server
cloudbrowser.description: An MCP server providing browser automation capabilities through Browserbase API
cloudbrowser.usageInstructions: 1. Run using 'npx -y @browsercloud/mcp-server-cloudbrowser'. 2. Configure Claude Desktop with the server settings, including API_KEY. 3. Restart Claude Desktop to access browser automation tools.

backlinks.name: SEO MCP
backlinks.description: An SEO tool service based on Ahrefs data, providing backlink analysis, keyword research, traffic estimation, and CAPTCHA solving via CapSolver.
backlinks.usageInstructions: 1. Install the package via pip or uv. 2. Set the CAPSOLVER_API_KEY environment variable with your CapSolver API key. 3. Use the service in Cursor IDE by adding the MCP server configuration. 4. Call API functions like get_backlinks_list, keyword_generator, get_traffic, and keyword_difficulty with appropriate parameters.

flux-img.name: Flux Image MCP Server
flux-img.description: MCP server providing image generation capabilities using Flux Schnell model on Replicate.
flux-img.installCommand: npm install -g @modelcontextprotocol/sdk@latest && git clone https://github.com/ckz/flux-img-mcp.git && cd flux-img-mcp && npm install && npm run build
flux-img.usageInstructions: 1. Configure REPLICATE_API_TOKEN in MCP settings file. 2. Add server configuration to MCP settings. 3. Use 'generate_image' tool with required 'prompt' parameter.

javascript.name: Clerk JavaScript SDKs
javascript.description: Clerk provides user management solutions with authentication and multi-tenancy features for web applications.
javascript.usageInstructions: 1. Sign up for a Clerk account at https://dashboard.clerk.com/sign-up. 2. Create an application in your Clerk Dashboard. 3. Install the Clerk SDK using 'npm install @clerk/nextjs'. 4. Configure your Clerk API key and frontend API URL as environment variables.

clay.name: Clay MCP Server
clay.description: A Model Context Protocol (MCP) server for Clay, enabling features like contact search, interaction tracking, and group management.
clay.usageInstructions:
1. Generate your Clay API key from https://web.clay.earth/settings/api-keys.
2. Run the install command: npx -y @clayhq/clay-mcp@latest.
3. Set the CLAY_API_KEY environment variable with your key.
4. Configure the MCP server in claude_desktop_config.json by adding the command and environment variables as shown in the README.

cloudflare.name: Cloudflare MCP Server
cloudflare.description: A Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that connects to Cloudflare services, allowing MCP clients to interact with Cloudflare's tools using natural language.
cloudflare.usageInstructions:
1. Install the MCP client of your choice (e.g., Cursor, Claude, or OpenAI's Responses API).
2. Access the remote MCP server by providing the server URL directly in the client interface or by configuring the client's configuration file using `mcp-remote`.
3. Set the required `CLOUDFLARE_API_TOKEN` environment variable with the appropriate permissions for the Cloudflare service you want to use.
4. Optionally, set additional parameters like `CLOUDFLARE_ZONE_ID` or `CLOUDFLARE_ACCOUNT_ID` for more specific interactions.
5. Use natural language queries to interact with the server and perform tasks such as debugging logs, managing Workers, or fetching analytics data.

custom-gitlab.name: Custom GitLab MCP Server
custom-gitlab.description: A custom GitLab MCP server implementation for integration with Claude and other MCP-compliant AI assistants.
custom-gitlab.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/chris-miaskowski/custom-gitlab-mcp-server.git && cd custom-gitlab-mcp-server && npm install
custom-gitlab.usageInstructions: 1. Clone the repository and install dependencies using 'npm install'. 2. Configure the server in your Claude settings file with the appropriate command and arguments. 3. Set GITLAB_PERSONAL_ACCESS_TOKEN and GITLAB_API_URL environment variables. 4. Ensure Node.js (v14 or higher) is installed.

chromia.name: Chromia MCP
chromia.description: A Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that enables Claude AI to interact with the Chromia Wallet for sending $CHR transactions.
chromia.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/chromindscan/chromia-mcp && cd chromia-mcp && cp .env.sample .env && npm i && npm run build
chromia.usageInstructions: 1. Clone the repository and copy the `.env.sample` file to `.env`. 2. Install dependencies with `npm i` and build the project with `npm run build`. 3. Configure the Claude Desktop App by editing its configuration file and adding the Chromia MCP server command. 4. Restart the Claude Desktop App to use the integration.

agentkit.name: Chargebee AgentKit MCP Server
agentkit.description: Toolkit to integrate Chargebee with AI applications for billing and subscription management
agentkit.usageInstructions:
1. Install using npm install -g @chargebee/mcp-server
2. Set required environment variables: CHARGEBEE_API_KEY and CHARGEBEE_SITE
3. Run the server
4. Configure with AI applications like Claude or Cursor

chatsum.name: mcp-server-chatsum
chatsum.description: An MCP server that summarizes chat messages by querying and processing chat databases.
chatsum.usageInstructions:
1. Create a `.env` file in the root directory and set the `CHAT_DB_PATH` to your chat database path.
2. Run `pnpm install` to install dependencies.
3. Run `pnpm build` to build the server.
4. For development, use `pnpm watch` for auto-rebuild.
5. To use with Claude Desktop, add the server configuration to the appropriate config file (MacOS: `~/Library/Application Support/Claude/claude_desktop_config.json`, Windows: `%APPDATA%/Claude/claude_desktop_config.json`) with the command and arguments pointing to the built server and the `CHAT_DB_PATH` environment variable set.

dev-portal.name: Chainstack Developer Portal
dev-portal.description: The Chainstack Developer Portal is a documentation platform built with Mintlify, providing interactive API references and built-in MCP server integration for local development.
dev-portal.installCommand: npm i -g mintlify && npx @mintlify/mcp@latest add chainstack
dev-portal.usageInstructions: To use the Developer Portal, browse the documentation and interact with the RPC node API reference. For local development, install the Mintlify CLI with `npm i -g mintlify`, then run `mintlify dev` from the project root. To add the Developer Portal as a local MCP server, run `npx @mintlify/mcp@latest add chainstack`. For release notes, follow the provided structure in the changelog directory and update the necessary files.

finnhub.name: Finnhub MCP Server
finnhub.description: An MCP server to interface with Finnhub API, providing financial data and market news.
finnhub.installCommand: uv sync && source .venv/bin/activate && fastmcp install server.py
finnhub.usageInstructions: 1. Install uv and run 'uv sync' to install dependencies. 2. Create .env file with FINNUB_API_KEY. 3. Run 'fastmcp install server.py'. 4. Configure Claude Desktop config file with the absolute path to uv executable. 5. Restart Claude Desktop.

mac-shell.name: Mac Shell MCP Server
mac-shell.description: An MCP server for executing macOS terminal commands with ZSH shell, featuring command whitelisting and approval mechanisms.
mac-shell.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/cfdude/mac-shell-mcp.git && cd mac-shell-mcp && npm install && npm run build
mac-shell.usageInstructions: Start the server with 'npm start' or 'node build/index.js'. Configure in Roo Code or Claude Desktop by specifying the path to the server executable. For npx usage, publish to npm or use 'github:cfdude/mac-shell-mcp'.

nrepl.name: Basilisp nREPL MCP Bridge
nrepl.description: Bridge between Anthropic's Model Control Protocol (MCP) and Basilisp's nREPL server, enabling Claude Code to interact with a Basilisp REPL.
nrepl.installCommand: uv pip install basilisp && basilisp nrepl-server --port 36915 & claude mcp add /path/to/basilisp_mcp_bridge.py
nrepl.usageInstructions:
1. Start Basilisp nREPL server: basilisp nrepl-server --port 36915
2. Add MCP bridge to Claude Code: claude mcp add /path/to/basilisp_mcp_bridge.py
3. Use available tools: eval_code(code), get_docs(symbol), find_namespace_vars(namespace), list_namespaces(), check_connection()

catapulta.name: Catapulta MCP Server
catapulta.description: A Model Context Protocol (MCP) implementation for Catapulta CLI, enabling AI-powered interactions with deployment and management tools.
catapulta.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/catapulta-sh/catapulta-mcp.git && cd catapulta-mcp && npm install
catapulta.usageInstructions: 1. Clone the repository and install dependencies. 2. Import and initialize the McpServer with StdioServerTransport. 3. Use the server to generate deployment commands with optional parameters like network, sponsor, gas_hawk, and script_path. 4. Configure in Cursor or VS Code by adding the server as a global MCP server with the command 'npx -y @catapulta/mcp-server@latest'.

cf-kaizen.name: cf-kaizen
cf-kaizen.description: A multi-module Spring Boot project providing a natural language interface for interacting with Cloud Foundry foundations using Spring AI and Model Context Protocol (MCP).
cf-kaizen.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/cf-toolsuite/cf-kaizen && cd cf-kaizen && mvn clean install
cf-kaizen.usageInstructions:
1. Clone the repository and navigate to the project directory.
2. Build the project using Maven: mvn clean install.
3. Set required environment variables: CF_APP_DOMAIN and CF_BUTLER_API_ENDPOINT.
4. Run the Butler server: cd butler && mvn spring-boot:run -Dspring-boot.run.profiles=cloud,dev.
5. Run the Butler client: cd clients/butler && mvn spring-boot:run -Dspring-boot.run.profiles=openai,dev.
6. Access the Butler frontend at http://localhost:8081.
7. For integration with Claude Desktop, create a configuration file with the appropriate Java command and paths.

mac.name: Mac Messages MCP
mac.description: A Python bridge for interacting with macOS Messages app using MCP, enabling universal message sending and reading.
mac.usageInstructions: 1. Install uv package manager. 2. Grant Full Disk Access permission to your terminal. 3. Run 'mac-messages-mcp' to start the server. For Claude Desktop integration, add configuration to claude_desktop_config.json. For Cursor integration, use 'uvx mac-messages-mcp' as the MCP command.

nhl-go.name: NHL MCP Server
nhl-go.description: A Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that exposes NHL API data for integration with LLMs.
nhl-go.usageInstructions:
1. Clone the repository: `git clone https://github.com/carsonjones/nhl-go.git && cd nhl-go`
2. Build the `nhl-mcp` binary: `cd ./mcp && go build -o nhl-mcp`
3. Add the path to the `nhl-mcp` binary to your `claude_desktop_config.json` file under the `nhl` key with the `command` field.
4. Use the MCP server to integrate NHL data with LLMs.

system.name: DevEnvInfoServer
system.description: A Cursor Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that provides detailed information about your development environment to the Cursor code editor, enabling more context-aware assistance.
system.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/carterlasalle/system_information_mcp.git && cd system_information_mcp && python -m venv venv && source venv/bin/activate && pip install -r requirements.txt
optionalParams: custom output file path for markdown (development_environment_info.md)
system.usageInstructions: 1. Clone the repository and navigate into the directory. 2. Create and activate a Python virtual environment. 3. Install dependencies using pip. 4. Configure Cursor to connect to the server by specifying the command to run `claudemcp.py`. 5. Optionally, generate a Markdown file containing all collected environment information.

winterm.name: WinTerm MCP
winterm.description: A Model Context Protocol server providing programmatic access to the Windows terminal for AI model interaction.
winterm.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/capecoma/winterm-mcp.git && cd winterm-mcp && npm install && npm run build
winterm.usageInstructions: 1. Clone the repository and install dependencies. 2. Build the project using 'npm run build'. 3. Configure Claude Desktop by adding server config to '%APPDATA%/Claude/claude_desktop_config.json'. 4. Use available tools like write_to_terminal, read_terminal_output, and send_control_character.

xcodebuildmcp.name: XcodeBuild MCP
xcodebuildmcp.description: An MCP server providing Xcode-related tools for AI assistants and MCP clients
xcodebuildmcp.usageInstructions: Configure your MCP client to use XcodeBuildMCP by setting the command to 'npx' with args ['-y', 'xcodebuildmcp@latest']. Ensure you have macOS 14.5+, Xcode 16.x+, and Node 18.x+ installed.

google-gmail.name: Gmail MCP Server
google-gmail.description: A powerful Model Context Protocol (MCP) server providing comprehensive Gmail integration with LLM processing capabilities.
google-gmail.usageInstructions: 1. Install using 'npm install -g @cablate/mcp-gmail'. 2. Run 'mcp-gmail' to start the server. 3. For Dive Desktop integration, follow the configuration steps provided in the README, including setting up Gmail API authentication credentials.

caiyun-weather.name: Caiyun Weather MCP Server
caiyun-weather.description: MCP server providing weather data through Caiyun Weather API, including real-time, hourly, and daily forecasts.
caiyun-weather.usageInstructions: 1. Install uv using: curl -LsSf https://astral.sh/uv/install.sh | sh (on MacOS/Linux) or powershell -ExecutionPolicy ByPass -c "irm https://astral.sh/uv/install.ps1 | iex" (on Windows). 2. Set CAIYUN_WEATHER_API_TOKEN environment variable with your Caiyun Weather API token. 3. Configure Claude Desktop by adding mcpServers configuration in claude_desktop_config.json.

bazi.name: Bazi MCP
bazi.description: An AI-powered Bazi calculator MCP server for accurate Chinese metaphysics analysis, providing precise Bazi data for personality analysis, destiny forecasting, and AI agent integration.
bazi.usageInstructions:
1. Ensure Node.js 22 or higher is installed.
2. Install the Bazi MCP server using the provided install command.
3. Configure AI applications (e.g., Claude Desktop) with the MCP server configuration as shown in the README.
4. Use the `getBaziDetail` tool with required parameters like solarDatetime or lunarDatetime to calculate Bazi results.

tuyactl.name: Tuya Command Line Interface (tuyactl)
tuyactl.description: A command-line interface for controlling Tuya devices using local keys obtained via the tinytuya setup wizard.
tuyactl.installCommand: curl -LsSf https://astral.sh/uv/install.sh | sh && uv pip install tuyactl
tuyactl.usageInstructions: 1. Install `uv` using the provided curl command. 2. Obtain Tuya local keys via the tinytuya setup wizard and save the `snapshot.json` file. 3. Set the `TUYA_SNAPSHOT_PATH` environment variable to the location of the `snapshot.json` file. 4. Run the Tuya server with `nohup tuyad > tuyad.log 2>&1 &`. 5. Use `tuyactl --help` to view available commands and options.

alphavantage.name: Alpha Vantage MCP Server
alphavantage.description: An MCP server for the Alpha Vantage stock market data API, providing access to real-time and historical financial data.
alphavantage.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/calvernaz/alphavantage.git && cd alphavantage && uv pip install -r requirements.txt
alphavantage.usageInstructions: 1. Clone the repository using the install command. 2. Set the ALPHAVANTAGE_API_KEY environment variable with your free API key from https://www.alphavantage.co. 3. Run the server in Stdio mode with 'alphavantage' or in HTTP mode with 'alphavantage --server http --port 8080'. 4. For use with Claude Desktop, configure the 'mcpServers' section in your 'claude_desktop_config.json' as shown in the README.

ui-tars-desktop.name: UI-TARS Desktop
ui-tars-desktop.description: A desktop application that provides a native GUI Agent based on the UI-TARS model, offering local and remote computer and browser operators for enhanced automation and control.
ui-tars-desktop.usageInstructions: After installation, launch the UI-TARS Desktop application. Configure the local model path and connect to remote operators if needed. Use the CLI or Web UI to execute tasks involving GUI automation, browser control, and multimodal AI agent workflows.

geoapify.name: Geoapify MCP Server
geoapify.description: Converts addresses to GPS coordinates and creates map images using Geoapify API
geoapify.usageInstructions:
1. Get Geoapify API key from https://www.geoapify.com/
2. Set GEO_APIKEY environment variable
3. Run server using 'uv run fastmcp run server.py'
4. Use 'get_gps_coordinates' to convert addresses to GPS coordinates
5. Use 'create_map_from_geojson' to create map images

dbhub.name: DBHub
dbhub.description: Universal database gateway implementing the Model Context Protocol (MCP) server interface
dbhub.usageInstructions: To use DBHub, specify the database connection using --dsn flag. For demo mode, use --demo flag. Supports PostgreSQL, MySQL, MariaDB, SQL Server, and SQLite databases.

webscan.name: MCP Webscan Server
webscan.description: An MCP server for web content scanning and analysis, providing tools for fetching, analyzing, and extracting information from web pages.
webscan.usageInstructions: 1. Configure the server in Claude Desktop settings with the correct path to the build/index.js file. 2. Use tools like fetch-page, extract-links, crawl-site in your conversations.

bucket-javascript-sdk.name: Bucket JavaScript SDK
bucket-javascript-sdk.description: A TypeScript-based feature flag SDK for SaaS applications, offering React, Vue, Browser, and Node.js SDKs for client and server-side usage.
bucket-javascript-sdk.usageInstructions: After installation, set the required environment variables (BUCKET_API_KEY and BUCKET_PROJECT_ID) and configure the SDK in your application. Refer to the specific SDK documentation for integration details.

video-editing.name: Video Editor MCP Server
video-editing.description: A Model Context Protocol (MCP) server for uploading, editing, searching, and generating videos using LLMs and Video Jungle integration.
video-editing.usageInstructions: 1. Sign up for an account at Video Jungle and obtain your API key. 2. Run the server using 'uv run video-editor-mcp YOURAPIKEY'. 3. For local Photos app access, set 'LOAD_PHOTOS_DB=1' before starting the server. 4. Use the provided tools (add-video, search-videos, generate-edit-from-videos, etc.) to manage and edit videos.

file-context.name: File Context Server
file-context.description: An MCP server providing file system context to LLMs with advanced caching and real-time file watching capabilities.
file-context.usageInstructions: Start the server using 'npx file-context-server'. Configure using environment variables MAX_CACHE_SIZE, CACHE_TTL, and MAX_FILE_SIZE.

mailchimpmcp.name: Mailchimp MCP Server
mailchimpmcp.description: Utilities for developing an MCP server for the Mailchimp API
mailchimpmcp.usageInstructions: 1. Install using npm install mailchimp-mcp. 2. Set MAILCHIMP_API_KEY environment variable. 3. Configure additional options like MAILCHIMP_API_ENDPOINT if needed. 4. Start the MCP server.

node-omnibus.name: Node Omnibus MCP Server
node-omnibus.description: A comprehensive Model Context Protocol (MCP) server providing Node.js development tooling and automation capabilities.
node-omnibus.usageInstructions:
1. Install via Smithery using: npx -y @smithery/cli install @bsmi021/mcp-node-omnibus-server --client claude
2. Alternatively, clone the repository and run: npm install && npm start
3. Integrate with MCP-compatible clients
4. Requires Node.js >=14.x, npm >=6.x, TypeScript >=4.x

npm.name: NPM Documentation MCP Server
npm.description: An MCP server that fetches metadata and documentation for NPM packages using the npms.io API and caches results locally with SQLite.
npm.usageInstructions:
1. Clone the repository if needed.
2. Run `npm install` to install dependencies.
3. Run `npm run build` to compile TypeScript to JavaScript.
4. Start the server using `node dist/server.js`.
5. Configure the server in your MCP client (e.g., Cline) by specifying the absolute path to the compiled server.js file and optional environment variables like `NPM_CACHE_TTL`, `NPM_CACHE_DB_PATH`, and `LOG_LEVEL`.

mistral-codestral.name: Mistral Codestral MCP Server
mistral-codestral.description: An MCP server implementation for the Mistral Codestral API, providing code completion, bug fixing, and test generation capabilities.
mistral-codestral.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/bsmi021/mcp-mistral-codestral && cd mcp-mistral-codestral && npm install && cp .env.example .env && npm run build
mistral-codestral.usageInstructions: 1. Clone the repository and install dependencies using `npm install`. 2. Copy `.env.example` to `.env` and add your Mistral API key. 3. Build the project with `npm run build`. 4. Start the server using `npm start`. 5. Use the `code_completion` tool with parameters `code`, `language`, and `task` to process code for completion, bug fixing, or test generation.

deltatask.name: DeltaTask
deltatask.description: A locally-hosted task management application with Obsidian integration and a Model Context Protocol (MCP) server for advanced task management and automation.
deltatask.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/brysontang/DeltaTask && cd DeltaTask && uv venv && source .venv/bin/activate && uv pip install -r requirements.txt
deltatask.usageInstructions:
1. Clone the repository and set up the Python environment using `uv`.
2. Activate the virtual environment and install dependencies.
3. Configure the DeltaTask server in Claude for Desktop by editing the `claude_desktop_config.json` file with the correct path to the server script.
4. Use the DeltaTask tools in Claude for Desktop by clicking the hammer icon.
5. Optionally, configure environment variables like `DATABASE_PATH` and `OBSIDIAN_VAULT_PATH` for custom paths.

browserbase.name: Browserbase MCP Server
browserbase.description: Enables LLMs to interact with web pages using cloud browser automation via Browserbase and Stagehand, supporting features like screenshots, data extraction, and JavaScript execution.
browserbase.usageInstructions: After installation, set the required environment variables (BROWSERBASE_API_KEY and STAGEHAND_API_KEY) and start the server. Use the provided APIs to control cloud browsers, extract data, and execute JavaScript. For detailed setup, refer to the Browserbase and Stagehand documentation.

cline-personas.name: Cline Personas MCP Server
cline-personas.description: An MCP server for managing .clinerules files using shared components and persona templates with mustache-style variable substitution.
cline-personas.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/bradfair/mcp-cline-personas && cd mcp-cline-personas && npm install && npm run build
cline-personas.usageInstructions: 1. Clone the repository and install dependencies with `npm install`. 2. Build the project with `npm run build`. 3. Use the `ComponentPersonaService` to manage components and personas. 4. Activate personas by calling `activatePersona(name)`. 5. Run the MCP server with `npm start`.

esxi.name: ESXi MCP Server
esxi.description: VMware ESXi/vCenter management server providing REST API for virtual machine management
esxi.installCommand: pip install pyvmomi pyyaml uvicorn mcp-core
esxi.usageInstructions:
1. Create config.yaml with required vCenter details
2. Run server with: python server.py -c config.yaml
3. Use API endpoints with proper authentication

slowtime.name: Slowtime MCP Server
slowtime.description: A Model Context Protocol server for secure time-based operations with timing attack protection and timelock encryption.
slowtime.usageInstructions: 1. Configure Claude Desktop by adding the server to ~/Library/Application Support/Claude/claude_desktop_config.json. 2. Start the server using 'node /path/to/build/index.js'. 3. Use interval commands like start_interval, check_interval, pause_interval, and resume_interval.

penrose.name: Penrose MCP Server
penrose.description: A Model Context Protocol (MCP) server for Penrose, enabling the creation of mathematical diagrams through natural language.
penrose.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/bmorphism/penrose-mcp && cd penrose-mcp && npm install
penrose.usageInstructions: After installation, use the provided justfile to access documentation and reference materials. For example: 'just architecture' to view the server architecture or 'just mcp-spec' to access MCP specifications. The server is primarily used for research and development of Penrose's diagramming capabilities.

marginalia.name: Marginalia MCP Server
marginalia.description: An MCP server providing access to Marginalia Search API for non-commercial content discovery
marginalia.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/bmorphism/marginalia-mcp-server.git && cd marginalia-mcp-server && npm install && npm run build
marginalia.usageInstructions: After installation, configure MARGINALIA_API_KEY if needed. The server provides an MCP tool 'search' with parameters: query (required), index (optional), and count (optional). Example usage: mcp.useTool('marginalia', 'search', { query: 'non-commercial websites', count: 5 })

square.name: Square MCP Server
square.description: An MCP server providing access to Square API functionality.
square.usageInstructions: 1. Set SQUARE_ACCESS_TOKEN environment variable. 2. Run 'square-mcp' to start the server. For development, use 'mcp dev src/square_mcp/server.py' after activating the virtual environment.

babashka.name: Babashka MCP Server
babashka.description: An MCP server for executing Babashka code and managing command history
babashka.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/bmorphism/babashka-mcp-server && cd babashka-mcp-server && npm install && npm run build
babashka.usageInstructions: 1. Install Babashka using the provided installation commands for your OS. 2. Verify Babashka installation. 3. Clone the repository and run 'npm install && npm run build'. 4. Configure BABASHKA_PATH environment variable if necessary.

anti-bullshit.name: Anti-Bullshit MCP Server
anti-bullshit.description: A Model Context Protocol server for analyzing claims, validating sources, and detecting manipulation using multiple epistemological frameworks.
anti-bullshit.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/bmorphism/anti-bullshit-mcp-server && cd anti-bullshit-mcp-server && npm install && npm run build
anti-bullshit.usageInstructions:
1. Clone the repository and install dependencies with 'npm install'.
2. Build the server with 'npm run build'.
3. Add the server to Claude Desktop by updating the config file at '~/Library/Application Support/Claude/claude_desktop_config.json' with the server command.
4. Use the analyze_claim, validate_sources, and check_manipulation functions with appropriate parameters to evaluate claims, sources, and manipulation tactics.

web-browser.name: Web Browser MCP Server
web-browser.description: Enables AI assistants to browse and extract content from websites via the Message Control Protocol (MCP) with smart content extraction, error handling, and cross-platform support.
web-browser.usageInstructions: 1. Install using `uv tool install web-browser-mcp-server`. 2. Configure your MCP client with the provided JSON configuration. 3. Use the `browse_webpage` tool to fetch and extract content from web pages. 4. For development, clone the repository and install with `uv pip install -e .[test]`.

hypernym.name: Hypernym MCP Server
hypernym.description: A Model Context Protocol (MCP) server providing semantic text analysis and compression tools via Hypernym AI's API.
hypernym.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/hypernym/hypernym-mcp-server.git && cd hypernym-mcp-server && npm install
hypernym.usageInstructions:
1. Clone the repository and install dependencies.
2. Create a .env file with HYPERNYM_API_URL and HYPERNYM_API_KEY.
3. Build the project with 'npm run build'.
4. Start the server with 'npm start' for HTTP/HTTPS mode or 'npm run start:stdio' for stdio transport mode.
5. Use the provided JSON-RPC 2.0 examples or integrate with MCP-compatible AI platforms using the .mcp.json configuration.

usgs-quakes.name: USGS Quakes MCP Server
usgs-quakes.description: An MCP server implementation for providing access to the USGS Quakes API within Claude Desktop.
usgs-quakes.usageInstructions: 1. Install via Smithery using the provided command. 2. For manual installation: Install Node.js, clone the repository, and configure Claude Desktop by editing claude_desktop_config.json to point to the server location.

macrostrat.name: Macrostrat MCP Server
macrostrat.description: An MCP server implementation for providing access to the Macrostrat API within Claude Desktop, enabling geological data queries.
macrostrat.installCommand: npx -y @smithery/cli install @blake365/macrostrat-mcp --client claude && npm install && npm run build
optionalParams: Custom server configuration options in claude_desktop_config.json
macrostrat.usageInstructions:
1. Install the server using the provided install command.
2. Edit the `src/index.ts` file if modifications are needed.
3. Run `npm install` to install dependencies.
4. Run `npm run build` to build the server.
5. Add the server configuration to the Claude Desktop config file (`claude_desktop_config.json`) under the `mcpServers` section.
6. Restart Claude Desktop to use the server.

playwright-plus-python.name: Playwright Server MCP
playwright-plus-python.description: An MCP server implementing Playwright tools for browser automation and interaction.
playwright-plus-python.usageInstructions: To use this MCP server, configure it in Claude Desktop by adding the server details to the claude_desktop_config.json file. For development, use 'uv sync' to sync dependencies, 'uv build' to build distributions, and 'uv publish' to publish to PyPI. Debugging can be done using the MCP Inspector via 'npx @modelcontextprotocol/inspector uv --directory <path> run playwright-server'.

speckle.name: Speckle MCP Server
speckle.description: An MCP server for interacting with Speckle, a collaborative data hub for AEC tools.
speckle.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/bimgeek/speckle-mcp.git && cd speckle-mcp && uv pip install -r requirements.txt
speckle.usageInstructions: 1. Clone the repository and install dependencies. 2. Set SPECKLE_TOKEN environment variable. 3. Configure MCP configuration file with server details.

adjust.name: Adjust MCP
adjust.description: A Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that interfaces with the Adjust API, enabling on-demand querying of metrics, reports, and performance data from any MCP client.
adjust.usageInstructions:
1. Get your Adjust API key from your Adjust account settings.
2. Install via Smithery using the provided command for your MCP client (e.g., Cursor or Claude Desktop).
3. For local development, clone the repo, run `npm run build`, and execute the server with your API key.
4. Query Adjust data using natural language commands like 'use adjust report revenue for the last 7 days'.

neovim.name: Neovim MCP Server
neovim.description: Connects Claude Desktop or any Model Context Protocol client to Neovim using MCP, enabling AI text assistance through Vim's native commands and workflows.
neovim.usageInstructions:
1. Start Neovim with a socket file, e.g., `nvim --listen /tmp/nvim`.
2. Set `NVIM_SOCKET_PATH` to the socket path (default is `/tmp/nvim`).
3. Optionally enable shell commands by setting `ALLOW_SHELL_COMMANDS=true`.
4. Use the MCP client to connect to the server and leverage tools like `vim_buffer`, `vim_command`, and `vim_edit` for text editing and navigation.

shiprocket.name: Shiprocket MCP Integration
shiprocket.description: MCP server for Shiprocket integration, enabling order management, shipping rate calculation, and tracking.
shiprocket.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/bfrs/shiprocket-mcp.git && cd shiprocket-mcp && npm install && npm run build
shiprocket.usageInstructions: 1. Configure claude_desktop_config.json or mcp.json with server details. 2. Add SELLER_EMAIL and SELLER_PASSWORD to env. 3. Start Claude Desktop or Cursor to use Shiprocket integration.

binary-reader.name: Binary Reader MCP
binary-reader.description: A Model Context Protocol server for reading and analyzing binary files, with initial support for Unreal Engine asset files (.uasset).
binary-reader.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/berlinbra/binary-reader-mcp.git && cd binary-reader-mcp && python -m venv venv && source venv/bin/activate && pip install -r requirements.txt
binary-reader.usageInstructions: Activate the virtual environment and use the provided tools through the Model Context Protocol. For example, to read an Unreal asset file, use the 'read-unreal-asset' tool with the 'file_path' argument. To read generic binary files, use the 'read-binary-metadata' tool with 'file_path' and optional 'format' parameter.

bifrostmcp.name: Bifrost MCP Server
bifrostmcp.description: VSCode extension providing MCP server for AI coding assistants
bifrostmcp.usageInstructions:
1. Install extension from VS Code marketplace
2. Configure AI assistant to connect to http://localhost:8008/sse
3. Optional: Create bifrost.config.json for project-specific configuration

run-command.name: Run Shell Command MCP Server
run-command.description: An MCP server that allows running shell commands
run-command.usageInstructions: To use, add an MCP in Cursor with Name: 'Run Command', Type: 'Command', and Command: 'npx github:benyue1978/run-command-mcp start'. Then use the 'shell command' prompt in Cursor chat to execute commands.

whois.name: Whois MCP
whois.description: Model Context Protocol (MCP) server for performing WHOIS lookups, allowing AI agents to retrieve domain, IP, and TLD information.
whois.usageInstructions:
1. Install using `npx -y @bharathvaj/whois-mcp@latest`.
2. For Cursor IDE: Add the server via Cursor Settings > MCP by specifying the command `npx -y @bharathvaj/whois-mcp@latest`.
3. For Roo Code: Configure the MCP server in the settings with the command `npx -y @bharathvaj/whois-mcp@latest`.
4. The server provides WHOIS lookup tools for domains, IPs, TLDs, and ASNs.
5. Use the tools directly in supported AI agents like Cursor or Roo Code.

serverman.name: mcp-serverman
serverman.description: A command-line tool to manage Claude MCP servers configuration with version control and profiling. It also includes a companion MCP server to let LLMs manage configurations.
serverman.usageInstructions: After installation, use `mcp-serverman` in the terminal. Initialize client configuration with `mcp-serverman client init`. Manage servers with commands like `enable`, `disable`, `remove`, and `list`. Use `mcp-serverman companion` to register the companion MCP server for LLM management. For detailed instructions, refer to the manual at https://github.com/benhaotang/mcp-serverman/blob/main/Manual.md.

mma-docs.name: Mathematica Documentation MCP Server
mma-docs.description: MCP server providing Mathematica documentation integration
mma-docs.installCommand: pip install -r requirements.txt && mcp dev path/to/mcp-mma-doc.py
mma-docs.usageInstructions: 1. Install requirements using 'pip install -r requirements.txt'. 2. Ensure Mathematica or wolframscript is installed. 3. Run 'mcp dev path/to/mcp-mma-doc.py' to initialize the server. 4. Configure Claude by adding the server details to its config file.

unipile.name: Unipile MCP Server
unipile.description: MCP server for integrating Unipile messaging platform with AI models
unipile.installCommand: docker pull buryhuang/mcp-unipile:latest && docker run -e UNIPILE_DSN=your_dsn_here -e UNIPILE_API_KEY=your_api_key_here buryhuang/mcp-unipile:latest
unipile.usageInstructions: 1. Obtain Unipile DSN and API key from Unipile dashboard. 2. Configure environment variables UNIPILE_DSN and UNIPILE_API_KEY. 3. Run using Docker command or build locally.

aws-resources-python.name: AWS Resources MCP Server
aws-resources-python.description: A Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that allows querying and managing AWS resources using Python and boto3 through a sandboxed execution environment.
aws-resources-python.usageInstructions: 1. Set AWS credentials via environment variables or AWS profile. 2. Run the Docker container with AWS credentials passed as environment variables or mounted AWS credentials file. 3. Use the server to execute Python code snippets that query or modify AWS resources via boto3.

mcprules.name: MCPRules - Programming Guidelines Management Server
mcprules.description: A Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that manages and serves programming guidelines and rules, integrating with development tools for consistent coding standards.
mcprules.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/bartwisch/MCPRules.git && cd MCPRules/rules-server && npm install && npm run build
mcprules.usageInstructions: 1. Clone the repository and navigate to the rules-server directory. 2. Install dependencies with npm install. 3. Build the server with npm run build. 4. Set the RULES_FILE_PATH environment variable to your rules file. 5. Optionally set GITHUB_TOKEN for private GitHub repositories. 6. Configure the server in VSCode Cline Extension or Claude Desktop with the provided JSON configuration.

tung-shing.name: Tung Shing MCP Service
tung-shing.description: Traditional Chinese calendar calculation service based on Model Context Protocol (MCP)
tung-shing.usageInstructions: Add the following to your MCP configuration file: { "mcpServers": { "tung-shing": { "command": "npx", "args": ["-y", "mcp-tung-shing@latest"] } } }

base.name: Base MCP Server
base.description: An MCP server providing onchain tools for AI applications to interact with the Base Network and Coinbase API, enabling wallet management, contract deployment, NFT handling, and more.
base.usageInstructions:
1. Install the package globally with 'npm install -g base-mcp'.
2. Create a .env file with required credentials (Coinbase API key, private key, wallet seed phrase, Coinbase Project ID, and Alchemy API key).
3. Optional: Add OpenRouter API key and Chain ID for additional functionality.
4. Initialize the server with 'base-mcp --init'.
5. Configure clients like Claude Desktop by adding the MCP server configuration to the appropriate JSON file with environment variables specified.

hubspot.name: HubSpot MCP Server
hubspot.description: An MCP server enabling AI assistants to interact with HubSpot CRM data, providing access to contacts, companies, and engagement data.
hubspot.usageInstructions: 1. Obtain a HubSpot access token with required scopes (crm.objects.contacts, crm.objects.companies, sales-email-read). 2. Run the Docker command with your access token. 3. For persistent storage, add volume mapping: -v /path/to/storage:/storage

zed-axiom-context.name: Axiom Context Server
zed-axiom-context.description: A Model Context Protocol (MCP) server for Axiom, used with the Zed AI assistant.
zed-axiom-context.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/axiomhq/zed-axiom-context-server && cd zed-axiom-context-server && npm install
zed-axiom-context.usageInstructions: After installation, configure the server in Zed's settings.json. Specify the command and arguments if the executable is not in the PATH. Example configuration: { "context_servers": { "axiom-mcp": { "settings": {}, "command": { "cmd": "/path/to/axiom-mcp", "args": ["--config", "/path/to/your/config.txt"] } } } }

auth0.name: Auth0 MCP Server
auth0.description: Auth0 MCP Server integrates with LLMs and AI agents to perform Auth0 management operations using natural language.
auth0.usageInstructions: 1. Install Node.js v18 or higher. 2. Install Claude Desktop or other MCP Client. 3. Create an Auth0 account. 4. Run 'npx @auth0/auth0-mcp-server init' to initialize. 5. Authorize with Auth0 through the OAuth2.0 device authorization flow. 6. Restart your MCP Client and use natural language to manage your Auth0 tenant.

axiom.name: mcp-server-axiom
axiom.description: An MCP server implementation for Axiom that allows AI agents to query data using Axiom Processing Language (APL).
axiom.usageInstructions: 1. Create a config file with your Axiom token and settings. 2. Configure the Claude app to use the MCP server by editing the claude_desktop_config.json file and specifying the server command and arguments. 3. Set environment variables or include them in the config file for Axiom credentials and rate limits.

intlayer.name: Intlayer
intlayer.description: Intlayer is a modern internationalization (i18n) solution that supports multiple frameworks like Next.js, React, Vite, and Express. It offers a JavaScript-powered content management system with TypeScript support, per-locale content declaration, and streamlined setup for efficient and type-safe translations.
intlayer.usageInstructions:
1. Install the package using `npm install intlayer`.
2. Initialize the project by running `npx intlayer init` to create the configuration file.
3. Configure the `intlayer.config.js` file to define your locales, content directory, and other settings.
4. Use the provided hooks and functions in your framework (e.g., React, Next.js) to retrieve and display translated content.
5. Run the build command `npx intlayer build` to generate localized content for deployment.

devcontext.name: DevContext
devcontext.description: An autonomous Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that provides intelligent context awareness for development workflows, integrating with codebases, conversations, and task management.
devcontext.usageInstructions:
1. Set up a TursoDB database by following the installation guide.
2. Configure the MCP server in your project's `.cursor/mcp.json` file with the database URL and auth token.
3. Implement the provided Cursor Rules for autonomous context management and task workflow integration.
4. Use the MCP tools in sequence: initialize_conversation_context, update_conversation_context, retrieve_relevant_context, record_milestone_context, and finalize_conversation_context.

cursor10x.name: Cursor10x MCP Server
cursor10x.description: An MCP server providing persistent memory layer for AI assistants with continuous context awareness
cursor10x.usageInstructions: 1. Configure Turso database: Install Turso CLI, login, create database, get URL and token. 2. Update .cursor/mcp.json with database credentials. 3. Run using 'npx cursor10x-mcp'

argus.name: Argus - Repository Analysis and Security Assessment Tool
argus.description: A powerful Model Context Protocol (MCP) tool for analyzing code repositories, performing security scans, and assessing code quality across multiple programming languages.
argus.usageInstructions: After installation, configure MCP commands as shown in the usage examples. Ensure system dependencies (libmagic) are installed according to the OS-specific instructions. For language-specific tools, follow the installation instructions provided in the Supported Analysis Tools section.

atla.name: Atla MCP Server
atla.description: An MCP server implementation providing a standardized interface for LLMs to interact with the Atla API for state-of-the-art LLMJ evaluation.
atla.usageInstructions: 1. Install `uv` and set up your Atla API key. 2. Run the server using `ATLA_API_KEY=<your-api-key> uvx atla-mcp-server`. 3. Connect to the server via OpenAI Agents SDK, Claude Desktop, or Cursor by configuring the respective tools with the `atla-mcp-server` command and API key.

doc-scraper.name: Doc Scraper MCP Server
doc-scraper.description: A Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that scrapes web-based documentation and converts it to markdown format using jina.ai's conversion service.
doc-scraper.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/askjohngeorge/mcp-doc-scraper.git && cd mcp-doc-scraper && python -m venv venv && source venv/bin/activate && pip install -e .
doc-scraper.usageInstructions: 1. Clone the repository and set up a virtual environment. 2. Install dependencies using pip install -e . 3. Run the server using python -m mcp_doc_scraper. 4. Use the 'scrape_docs' tool by providing a URL and an output path for the markdown file.

mtg-servers.name: MTG Deck Manager MCP Servers
mtg-servers.description: MCP servers for managing Magic: The Gathering decks and card information through Claude.
mtg-servers.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/artillect/mtg-deck-mcp-server.git && cd mtg-deck-mcp-server && python -m venv .venv && .venv\Scripts\activate && pip install fastmcp httpx
mtg-servers.usageInstructions: 1. Clone the repository and set up a Python virtual environment. 2. Configure Claude Desktop Client with the paths to the Python executables and server scripts. 3. Interact with the servers through Claude to manage MTG decks and search for card information.

scdl.name: scdl-mcp
scdl.description: An MCP server that enables downloading songs and playlists from SoundCloud using Claude or other LLM clients that support MCP.
scdl.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/arnavsurve/scdl-mcp && cd scdl-mcp && uv run mcp install server.py
scdl.usageInstructions: After installation, restart the Claude desktop client or any other LLM client that supports MCP. Use the server to download songs and playlists from SoundCloud by interacting with the LLM client. Ensure dependencies like ffmpeg and scdl are installed on your system.

sg-lta.name: Singapore LTA MCP Server
sg-lta.description: MCP server providing real-time Singapore LTA transportation data including bus arrivals, traffic conditions, and train service updates.
sg-lta.usageInstructions: 1. Register for LTA DataMall API key. 2. Configure claude_desktop_config.json with API key: { "mcpServers": { "lta": { "command": "npx", "args": ["-y", "arjunkmrm/mcp-sg-lta"], "env": { "LTA_API_KEY": "YOUR-API-KEY" } } } }

localutils.name: Local Utilities MCP Server
localutils.description: An MCP server providing various local system utilities for Cursor and other MCP-compatible clients.
localutils.usageInstructions: Start the server using 'localutils-mcp' after global installation, or 'npx localutils-mcp-server' without installation. Configure it as an MCP server in Cursor settings.

minecraft.name: Minecraft MCP Integration
minecraft.description: An MCP integration for Minecraft that enables AI assistants to interact with a Minecraft server through a bot, allowing observation and interaction with the Minecraft world.
minecraft.usageInstructions:
1. Install Minecraft server v1.21 and Java 21.0.5.
2. Use the provided install command or manually configure claude_desktop_config.json with the server.jar path.
3. Launch Minecraft Java Edition v1.21 and connect to localhost:25565.
4. Use MCP tools like `chat`, `moveForward`, `placeBlock`, and `getBlockInfo` to interact with the Minecraft world through the bot.

brave-search.name: Brave Search MCP Server
brave-search.description: An MCP server for Brave Search integration with AI assistants like Claude.
brave-search.usageInstructions:
1. Configure claude_desktop_config.json with MCP server settings
2. Set BRAVE_API_KEY environment variable
3. Start MCP-compatible AI assistant

kagi-search.name: Kagi MCP Server
kagi-search.description: MCP server that allows searching web using Kagi API, implementing tools for web search and news enrichment.
kagi-search.usageInstructions: After installation, configure Claude Desktop by adding the Kagi MCP server details in ~/Library/Application\ Support/Claude/claude_desktop_config.json, including the KAGI_API_KEY in the env section.

sequential-thinking.name: Sequential Thinking MCP Server
sequential-thinking.description: A Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that facilitates structured, progressive thinking through defined stages, enabling users to break down complex problems into sequential thoughts and generate summaries.
sequential-thinking.usageInstructions: 1. Set up the project by creating a virtual environment and installing dependencies using `uv venv` and `uv pip install -e .`. 2. Run the server using `uv run -m mcp_sequential_thinking.server` or the installed script `mcp-sequential-thinking`. 3. Use the `process_thought` tool to record thoughts in sequence, specifying parameters like thought content, stage, and metadata. 4. Generate summaries with `generate_summary` and reset the thinking process with `clear_history`.

superset.name: Superset MCP Integration
superset.description: MCP server for interacting with Apache Superset, enabling AI agents to connect to and control a Superset instance programmatically.
superset.usageInstructions: 1. Set up Superset locally using the provided script. 2. Clone this repository. 3. Create a .env file with Superset credentials. 4. Install dependencies with 'uv pip install .'. 5. Install MCP config with 'mcp install main.py'. 6. Use with Claude Desktop to interact with Superset via natural language commands.

xmind.name: MCP XMind Server
xmind.description: A Model Context Protocol server for analyzing and querying XMind mind maps, providing features like smart fuzzy search, task management, and hierarchical content navigation.
xmind.usageInstructions: To start the server, run: node dist/index.js <allowed-directory> [additional-directories...]. Configure using claude_desktop_config.json with appropriate command and args.

apisix.name: APISIX Model Context Protocol (MCP) Server
apisix.description: A Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that bridges large language models (LLMs) with the APISIX Admin API, enabling natural language-based interaction for managing APISIX resources.
apisix.usageInstructions:
1. Follow the APISIX Getting Started guide to set up and run APISIX.
2. Install the APISIX MCP server using the provided install command.
3. Configure your AI client (e.g., Cursor, Claude) with the server command and environment variables.
4. Use the MCP server to interact with APISIX resources via natural language commands in your AI client.

obsidian-omnisearch.name: MCP Server Obsidian Omnisearch
obsidian-omnisearch.description: A FastMCP-based server providing Obsidian vault search through REST API
obsidian-omnisearch.usageInstructions: 1. Install via Smithery CLI or manual installation. 2. Configure Obsidian Omnisearch plugin. 3. Run server with vault path: 'python server.py /path/to/obsidian/vault'. For Claude Desktop, configure claude_desktop_config.json with server details.

chart.name: MCP Server Chart
chart.description: A Model Context Protocol server for generating charts using AntV, supporting over 25 chart types including bar, pie, line, and map-based visualizations.
chart.usageInstructions: To use, run the server with `mcp-server-chart --transport sse` for SSE transport or `mcp-server-chart --transport streamable` for Streamable transport. Configure the server in your MCP client (e.g., VSCode, Cline) with the appropriate JSON configuration. For private deployment, set the VIS_REQUEST_SERVER environment variable to a custom service URL.

brianknows.name: BrianKnows MCP Server
brianknows.description: An MCP server connecting Claude to BrianKnows' blockchain knowledge base, providing tools for ping, search, and agent interactions.
brianknows.usageInstructions: 1. Install Claude Desktop. 2. Configure Claude Desktop with the MCP server settings using your BrianKnows API key. 3. Use commands like 'check BrianKnows API status', 'search for Ethereum Layer2', or 'ask about Uniswap V3'.

gibber.name: Tiny Cryptography MCP Server
gibber.description: A Model Context Protocol server providing cryptographic tools for key pair generation, shared secret derivation, and message encryption/decryption using the Stanford JavaScript Crypto Library (SJCL).
gibber.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/anton10xr/gibber-mcp && cd mcp-server && npm install
gibber.usageInstructions:
1. Clone the repository and install dependencies with 'npm install'.
2. Start the development server using 'npm run dev'.
3. For production, build the project with 'npm run build' and start the server with 'npm start'.
4. Use the provided API endpoints to interact with the server's cryptographic tools.

rocq.name: MCP-RoCQ Coq Reasoning Server
rocq.description: MCP-RoCQ is a Model Context Protocol server providing advanced logical reasoning through Coq proof assistant integration.
rocq.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/angrysky56/mcp-rocq.git && cd mcp-rocq && uv venv && ./venv/Scripts/activate && uv pip install -e .
rocq.usageInstructions: 1. Install Coq Platform 8.19. 2. Configure paths in mcphost config or Claude App config JSON. 3. Use type checking, inductive type definition, and property proving tools as shown in usage examples.

coinmarket.name: Coinmarket MCP Server
coinmarket.description: An MCP server implementing Coinmarket API endpoints for currency listings and quotes, with custom coinmarket:// URI scheme support
coinmarket.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/anjor/coinmarket-mcp-server.git && cd coinmarket-mcp-server && uv pip install -r requirements.txt
coinmarket.usageInstructions:
1. Set COINMARKET_API_KEY environment variable with your Coinmarket API key
2. Run using uv: uv run coinmarket_service
3. Or use Docker: docker run -e COINMARKET_API_KEY=your_api_key_here coinmarket-service
4. Configure Claude Desktop with the provided mcpServers configuration
5. Access endpoints via coinmarket:// URI scheme

simple-timeserver.name: MCP Simple Timeserver
simple-timeserver.description: An MCP server providing current local time and UTC time to Claude AI
simple-timeserver.usageInstructions: 1. Install using 'pip install mcp-simple-timeserver'. 2. Configure in Claude desktop app by adding 'mcpServers' configuration with appropriate Python executable path. For example: '"mcpServers": { "simple-timeserver": { "command": "python", "args": ["-m", "mcp_simple_timeserver"] } }' for Mac/Linux or use full Python path for Windows.

logic.name: MCP-Logic
logic.description: An MCP server providing automated reasoning capabilities using Prover9/Mace4 for AI systems, enabling logical theorem proving and model verification.
logic.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/angrysky56/mcp-logic && cd mcp-logic && chmod +x linux-setup-script.sh && ./linux-setup-script.sh
logic.usageInstructions: After installation, configure the LADR_DIR and PROVER9_PATH environment variables to point to the installed LADR/Prover9 binaries. Use the 'prove' tool to run logical proofs, and 'check-well-formed' to validate logical statements. For Docker-based usage, run the provided run-mcp-logic.sh or run-mcp-logic.bat scripts. Integration with Claude Desktop requires configuring the mcpServers section in the configuration file with the correct paths.

selenium.name: MCP Selenium Server
selenium.description: An MCP server implementation for Selenium WebDriver, enabling browser automation through standardized MCP clients.
selenium.usageInstructions: Start the server by running: mcp-selenium. Configure in MCP clients using: { "mcpServers": { "selenium": { "command": "npx", "args": ["-y", "@angiejones/mcp-selenium"] } } }

simple-openai-assistant.name: MCP Simple OpenAI Assistant
simple-openai-assistant.description: An MCP server for interacting with OpenAI assistants, allowing tools like Claude Desktop to create and communicate with OpenAI assistants.
simple-openai-assistant.usageInstructions: To use, configure the server in Claude Desktop by adding the OPENAI_API_KEY to the environment variables in the config. The command to run the server is 'python -m mcp_simple_openai_assistant'. For Windows, ensure the correct path to python.exe is used.

raindrop-io.name: Raindrop.io MCP Server
raindrop-io.description: An MCP server that integrates with Raindrop.io bookmarks, allowing LLMs to interact with bookmark data.
raindrop-io.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/anarcher/raindrop-io-mcp-server && cd raindrop-io-mcp-server && go mod tidy && go build -o raindrop-mcp-server
raindrop-io.usageInstructions: 1. Set RAINDROP_TOKEN in a .env file. 2. Configure Claude for Desktop by adding the server command to claude_desktop_config.json. 3. Restart Claude for Desktop.

nps.name: National Park Services MCP Server
nps.description: MCP Server providing interface to retrieve National Park Services data
nps.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/amysatterlee/nps && cd nps && npm install
nps.usageInstructions: 1. Clone repository and install dependencies. 2. Create .env file with NPS API key. 3. Run 'npm run build' and 'node ./build/server.js'. 4. Configure Claude Desktop to use this MCP server.

cloudflare-browser-rendering.name: Cloudflare Browser Rendering MCP Server
cloudflare-browser-rendering.description: MCP server providing web content extraction using Cloudflare Browser Rendering for LLM context
cloudflare-browser-rendering.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/amotivv/cloudflare-browser-rendering.git && cd cloudflare-browser-rendering && npm install
cloudflare-browser-rendering.usageInstructions:
1. Clone repository and install dependencies
2. Configure Wrangler and deploy Cloudflare Worker
3. Set BROWSER_RENDERING_API environment variable
4. Build and run MCP server using 'npm run build' and 'npm start'

installer.name: mcp-installer
installer.description: An MCP server that installs other MCP servers from npm, PyPi, or local paths for you.
installer.usageInstructions: 1. Add the mcp-installer configuration to your claude_desktop_config.json as shown in the README. 2. Use prompts like 'Install the MCP server named [server-name]' or provide a local path or package name. 3. For GitHub servers, set GITHUB_PERSONAL_ACCESS_TOKEN if needed.

ts-trello.name: Trello MCP Server (TypeScript)
ts-trello.description: A TypeScript implementation of a Model Context Protocol (MCP) server for Trello integration, providing tools for AI assistants to interact with Trello boards, lists, and cards.
ts-trello.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/andypost/mcp-server-ts-trello && cd mcp-server-ts-trello && make install
ts-trello.usageInstructions:
1. Clone the repository and install dependencies using `make install`.
2. Create a `.env` file with your Trello API credentials: `TRELLO_API_KEY` and `TRELLO_TOKEN`.
3. Build the project using `make build`.
4. Start the server with `make start`.
5. Use the provided MCP tools (`get_boards`, `get_lists`, `get_cards`, `get_card_details`) to interact with Trello boards, lists, and cards.

unichat.name: Unichat MCP Server
unichat.description: MCP server that sends requests to various AI models like OpenAI, MistralAI, and Anthropic using the MCP protocol.
unichat.usageInstructions: To use this server, configure it in Claude Desktop by adding the 'unichat-mcp-server' to 'mcpServers' in claude_desktop_config.json with appropriate environment variables. For development, use 'uv run unichat-mcp-server' in the project directory.

simple-pubmed.name: MCP Simple PubMed
simple-pubmed.description: An MCP server that provides access to PubMed articles through the Entrez API, allowing users to search for articles, access abstracts, and download full text for open-access articles.
simple-pubmed.usageInstructions: 1. Install the package using `pip install mcp-simple-pubmed`. 2. Set the required environment variable `PUBMED_EMAIL` with your email address. 3. Optionally set `PUBMED_API_KEY` for higher rate limits. 4. Add the server to your Claude Desktop configuration with the command `python -m mcp_simple_pubmed`. 5. Use the server to search PubMed for articles, retrieve abstracts, and download full text for open-access articles.

unichat-ts.name: Unichat MCP Server (TypeScript)
unichat-ts.description: A Model Context Protocol (MCP) server in TypeScript that allows sending requests to multiple AI vendors (OpenAI, MistralAI, Anthropic, xAI, Google AI, DeepSeek) via predefined prompts or custom tools. Supports both STDIO and SSE transport mechanisms.
unichat-ts.usageInstructions:
1. Install the server using `npx -y unichat-ts-mcp-server`.
2. Set the required environment variables: `UNICHAT_MODEL` (e.g., gpt-4o-mini) and `UNICHAT_API_KEY` (vendor-specific API key).
3. Run the server with `npx -y unichat-ts-mcp-server` for STDIO mode or `npx -y unichat-ts-mcp-server --sse` for SSE mode.
4. For debugging, use `npm run inspector` to launch the MCP Inspector and access debugging tools in your browser.
5. To use with Claude Desktop, add the server configuration to the appropriate config file (`claude_desktop_config.json`) with the command and environment variables specified.

simple-arxiv.name: mcp-simple-arxiv
simple-arxiv.description: An MCP server that provides access to arXiv papers through their API, allowing LLM clients to search for scientific papers and retrieve metadata and abstracts.
simple-arxiv.usageInstructions:
1. Install the package using pip install mcp-simple-arxiv.
2. Add the server configuration to your claude_desktop_config.json as shown in the README.
3. Restart Claude Desktop to access the server capabilities.
4. Use queries like 'search arXiv for recent papers about [topic]' or 'show me details for paper [ID]' to interact with the server.

adspirer.name: Adspirer MCP Server
adspirer.description: AI-powered advertising campaign management server for Claude, supporting Amazon Ads and other platforms.
adspirer.usageInstructions: 1. Get API key from Adspirer.com. 2. Run 'npm install -g adspirer-mcp-server'. 3. Configure Claude Desktop using 'adspirer-mcp config'. 4. Start using in Claude to manage ad campaigns.

name-origin.name: Name Origin Predictor MCP Server
name-origin.description: An MCP server that predicts name origins using Nationalize.io API
name-origin.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/allglenn/mcp-name-origin-server.git && cd mcp-name-origin-server && python3 -m venv venv && source venv/bin/activate && pip install httpx mcp-server
name-origin.usageInstructions:
1. Create claude_desktop_config.json with server configuration
2. Run 'python mcp-server.py' to start the server
3. Use predict_origin or batch_predict methods

unlock-pdf.name: MCP Unlock PDF Server
unlock-pdf.description: MCP server that enables clients to read protected or unprotected PDF files
unlock-pdf.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/algonacci/mcp-unlock-pdf && cd mcp-unlock-pdf && uv pip install -r requirements.txt
unlock-pdf.usageInstructions: To use this MCP server, add the configuration to your MCP config file as shown in the README. Ensure you have Python and uv installed. The command uses 'uv run python main.py', so make sure the path in the config is correct.

tavily-extract.name: MCP Tavily Extract Server
tavily-extract.description: MCP server for extracting web pages using Tavily API
tavily-extract.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/algonacci/mcp-tavily-extract && cd mcp-tavily-extract && pip install -r requirements.txt
tavily-extract.usageInstructions: 1. Clone the repository and install requirements. 2. Configure MCP config file with command and args. 3. Create .env file with TAVILY_API_KEY.

agenda.name: Agenda MCP Server
agenda.description: A server implementation for interacting with the Agenda app on macOS through Claude AI, providing tools to create notes, manage projects, and open existing notes.
agenda.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/alexgoller/mcp-server-agenda.git && cd mcp-server-agenda && pip install uv && uv pip install -e .
agenda.usageInstructions: 1. Clone the repository and cd into it. 2. Install uv using 'pip install uv'. 3. Create a pyproject.toml file with project dependencies. 4. Install project dependencies using 'uv pip install -e .'. 5. Configure Claude desktop config file at '$HOME/Library/Application Support/Claude/claude_desktop_config.json' with the server command and args.

gnews.name: mcp-gnews
gnews.description: MCP server that allows clients to search for related news on the internet.
gnews.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/algonacci/mcp-gnews && cd mcp-gnews && pip install -r requirements.txt
gnews.usageInstructions: Add the provided JSON configuration to your MCP config file. Ensure the path to the mcp-gnews directory is correct. Run the server using the specified command with uv.

ftp.name: MCP Server for FTP Access
ftp.description: This Model Context Protocol (MCP) server provides tools for interacting with FTP servers, allowing Claude.app to list directories, download and upload files, create directories, and delete files/directories on FTP servers.
ftp.usageInstructions: 1. Install the server using the provided command. 2. Configure the server by editing the Claude Desktop configuration file with the FTP server details. 3. Restart Claude Desktop to use the server. 4. Use natural language commands to perform FTP operations like listing directories, uploading/downloading files, and managing directories.

tools.name: MCP Tools
tools.description: A collection of Model Context Protocol (MCP) tools for various purposes.
tools.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/algonacci/mcp-tools && cd mcp-tools && pip install -r requirements.txt
tools.usageInstructions: Clone the repository and install the required dependencies. Explore the tools and scripts provided for Model Context Protocol (MCP) functionalities.

hh-jira.name: hh-jira-mcp-server
hh-jira.description: An MCP server project integrating with Jira
hh-jira.installCommand: brew install uv && uv pip install keyring && uvx hh-jira-mcp-server
hh-jira.usageInstructions: 1. Register at https://claude.ai and buy Pro subscription. 2. Install Claude Desktop. 3. Configure claude_desktop_config.json with the required env vars. 4. Store Jira password using: keyring set hh-jira-mcp-server <username>

solr.name: Solr MCP
solr.description: A Python package for accessing Apache Solr indexes via Model Context Protocol (MCP), enabling AI assistants to perform hybrid keyword and vector searches.
solr.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/allenday/solr-mcp && cd solr-mcp && python -m venv venv && source venv/bin/activate && pip install poetry && poetry install
solr.usageInstructions: 1. Clone the repository and set up the Python virtual environment. 2. Start SolrCloud using Docker with 'docker-compose up -d'. 3. Process and index documents using the provided scripts. 4. Run the MCP server with 'poetry run python -m solr_mcp.server'. Ensure required environment variables are set for Solr and Ollama integration.

illumio.name: Illumio MCP Server
illumio.description: A Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that provides an interface to interact with Illumio PCE (Policy Compute Engine) for workload management, label operations, and traffic flow analysis.
illumio.installCommand: git clone [repository-url] && cd illumio-mcp && pip install -r requirements.txt
illumio.usageInstructions: 1. Clone the repository and install dependencies. 2. Configure the server by adding it to the `mcpServers` section in your Claude Desktop configuration file with the required environment variables (PCE_HOST, PCE_PORT, PCE_ORG_ID, API_KEY, API_SECRET). 3. Use the server to manage workloads, labels, traffic flows, and perform security analysis via MCP interface.

chess.name: MCP Chess Server
chess.description: An MCP server providing chess functionality for Claude AI Assistant
chess.installCommand: Download the latest binary from https://github.com/alexandreroman/mcp-chess/releases and configure Claude Desktop
chess.usageInstructions: 1. Download binary from releases page. 2. Make executable (chmod +x). 3. Configure Claude Desktop through Settings > Developer > Edit Config. 4. Add MCP server configuration with binary path. 5. Restart Claude Desktop.

archai-static-analyzer.name: Archai Static Analyzer MCP Server
archai-static-analyzer.description: An MCP server for static analysis using Archai

metaplex.name: Metaplex MCP Server
metaplex.description: An MCP server for accessing Metaplex documentation and repository information
metaplex.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/metaplex-foundation/metaplex-mcp-server.git && cd metaplex-mcp-server && npm install && npm run build && node build/index.js
metaplex.usageInstructions: After installation, the server runs automatically. For development, use 'npm install' followed by 'npm run build && node build/index.js'

supernotes-to-obsidian.name: Supernotes to Obsidian
supernotes-to-obsidian.description: A Python script that imports Supernotes exports into Obsidian daily notes using the Model Context Protocol (MCP).
supernotes-to-obsidian.installCommand: uv venv && source .venv/bin/activate && uv add mcp
optionalParams: other configuration options available in config.py
supernotes-to-obsidian.usageInstructions: 1. Configure settings in config.py. 2. Run the script using 'python src/main.py'. Ensure you have Python and uv installed.

google-sheets.name: Google Sheets MCP
google-sheets.description: MCP integration with Google Sheets allowing LLM to interact with spreadsheets
google-sheets.installCommand: git clone https://github.com/akchro/google-sheets-mcp && cd google-sheets-mcp && npm install
google-sheets.usageInstructions:
1. Create a new Google Cloud project
2. Enable Google Drive API
3. Configure OAuth consent screen
4. Create OAuth Client ID for 'Desktop App'
5. Rename OAuth key file to 'credentials.json' and place in project root
6. Run 'npm start'

metal.name: Metal MCP Server
metal.description: An MCP server providing Metal Framework documentation search and code generation capabilities.
metal.installCommand: npx @modelcontextprotocol/create-server metal-mcp && cd metal-mcp && npm install && npm run build
metal.usageInstructions: After installation, add the server to your MCP configuration with the command `node` and the path to `metal-mcp/build/index.js`. Use the provided tools to search Metal documentation, generate code snippets, and access best practices and guides.

neurolora.name: MCP Neurolora
neurolora.description: An intelligent MCP server that provides tools for code analysis using OpenAI API, code collection, and documentation generation.
neurolora.usageInstructions:
1. Install Node.js 18 and uv/uvx as described in the README.
2. Run `npx -y @aindreyway/mcp-neurolora@latest` to start the server.
3. Set the `OPENAI_API_KEY` environment variable with your OpenAI API key.
4. Use the provided tools like `analyze_code`, `collect_code`, and `install_base_servers` by providing the required parameters in JSON format.

argocd.name: Argo CD MCP Server
